objects.author: deepti@thewebplant.com
objects.html_title: Just How Important is Content on your Website?
objects.label: Just How Important is Content on your Website?

meta.post_summary: When redesigning a website, more than just visual elements and coding go into making it even better than before. The saying “content is king” is popular for a reason - it makes a big impact on what happens after a visitor arrives at your website.
meta.html_title: Just How Important is Content on your Website?
meta.meta_description: We do digital marketing with results that matter. From social media, web design, to digital advertising. We do it all.
meta.post_body:
When redesigning a website, more than just visual elements and coding go into making it even better than before. The saying “content is king” is popular for a reason - it makes a big impact on what happens after a visitor arrives at your website.

 

Visitors are potential customers and clients. While on your website, these potential leads are looking for information about why they should choose you over one of your competitors.  

 

If your content is organized, simple to understand, optimized for search engines and personal to you and your company, it will make a substantial difference.

 

You website should answer the following questions: What do you do and how is it different from your competitors?

 

For best results, you should create a structure with that in mind so visitors easily find what they need. People tend to scan for what they’re looking for online rather than read every word. Make sure that the most important information is emphasized.

 

Similarly, your content needs to be simple and direct but not as simple as your ads! Remember, potential clients and customers come to your website to get more information about what they see in your ads. Make your website fresh, appropriate for your audience and make it fit well with your website design and structure.

 

Want to create that big impact with your website? We can help.  At Advocate Digital Media, copywriting is one of the many services we provide when helping create your website.

 

Our experts can come in and meet with you to learn more about your business and what you’re looking to say with your website, then create content for you based off of your needs. Contact us at ADM and learn more about what we can do for you.

objects.html_title: Longview Chamber of Commerce  Launches New Website
objects.label: Longview Chamber of Commerce  Launches New Website

meta.post_summary: The Longview Chamber of Commerce (LCC) has launched a completely redesigned website, www.longviewchamber.com. It was unveiled early July 2015, increasing the ease in which chamber members and the community can stay informed on the latest chamber developments.
meta.html_title: Longview Chamber of Commerce  Launches New Website
meta.meta_description: We do digital marketing with results that matter. From social media, web design, to digital advertising. We do it all.
meta.post_body:
The Longview Chamber of Commerce (LCC) has launched a completely redesigned website, www.longviewchamber.com. It was unveiled early July 2015, increasing the ease in which chamber members and the community can stay informed on the latest chamber developments. 

“Our mission is to engage in and promote projects that have a positive impact on the Longview Trade Area. The launch of our new site is just such a project. Our new site will increase our ability to serve our members,” Kelly Hall, President and CEO of the Longview Chamber of Commerce said. 

One of the biggest improvements to the site was a reorganization of the vast amount of information available on the website. Now things like blogs, news, membership info and searching are more accessible and organized than they were before. 

The Longview Chamber partnered with chamber member Advocate Digital Media on the design, implementation and management of the new site. Featuring responsive design, chamber members and the community can access the site easily on any platform – desktop, laptop, tablet or smartphone. 

“The one thing I’m really pleased with is how well the site works on all devices. So many people use their iPhone or iPad and our updated website works well on all them,” Paul Anderson, senior vice president of the Longview Chamber of Commerce said. 

The site also fully integrates social platforms to encourage engagement and sharing of local content and resources. 

“The end result is a web site that is visually stunning, loaded with the latest features, and offers ease at updating the content so it doesn’t become static,” Hall said. 

Advocate Digital Media’s full service agency has developed to be the area’s primary source for digital marketing solutions, attracting a diverse list of clients in both East Texas as well as South Texas, and is a leader in developing business-centered web sites. The agency simultaneously developed www.visitlongviewtexas.com for the Longview Convention and Visitors Bureau. 

“I really enjoyed working with the Advocate Digital Media team, they were excellent to work with and very responsive to questions and suggestions. It was great to have an excellent local company be at that level of expertise and available here in Longview,” Anderson said.

The Longview Chamber partnered with chamber member Advocate Digital Media on the design, implementation and management of the new site. Featuring responsive design, chamber members and the community can access the site easily on any platform – desktop, laptop, tablet or smartphone. 

“The one thing I’m really pleased with is how well the site works on all devices. So many people use their iPhone or iPad and our updated website works well on all them,” Paul Anderson, senior vice president of the Longview Chamber of Commerce said. 

The site also fully integrates social platforms to encourage engagement and sharing of local content and resources. 

“The end result is a web site that is visually stunning, loaded with the latest features, and offers ease at updating the content so it doesn’t become static,” Hall said. 

Advocate Digital Media’s full service agency has developed to be the area’s primary source for digital marketing solutions, attracting a diverse list of clients in both East Texas as well as South Texas, and is a leader in developing business-centered web sites. The agency simultaneously developed www.visitlongviewtexas.com for the Longview Convention and Visitors Bureau. 

“I really enjoyed working with the Advocate Digital Media team, they were excellent to work with and very responsive to questions and suggestions. It was great to have an excellent local company be at that level of expertise and available here in Longview,” Anderson said.

objects.author: deepti@thewebplant.com
objects.html_title: What’s The Deal With Bounce Rate?
objects.label: What’s The Deal With Bounce Rate?

meta.post_summary: We work with all kinds of business at Advocate Digital Media. From auto dealers and retail to health care providers and community organizations.
meta.html_title: What’s The Deal With Bounce Rate?
meta.meta_description: We do digital marketing with results that matter. From social media, web design, to digital advertising. We do it all.
meta.post_body:
We work with all kinds of business at Advocate Digital Media. From auto dealers and retail to health care providers and community organizations.

With a variety of organizations, the variety of leaders charged with handling marketing initiatives have varying goals and levels of understanding when it comes to marketing. This is particularly true when it comes to digital marketing.

After all, most business leaders are struggling to find enough time to actually run and grow their business, let alone worry about the marketing and nuances of digital marketing.

However, one particular metric that seems to be the most confounding to businesses of all sizes and sophistication is bounce rate.

To understand bounce rate it’s important to understand other key metrics within Google Analytics. Now keep in mind, in order to gain any insight into these metrics you must have Google Analytics installed and configured correctly on your website.

  • Users: Last year Google changed the way it reported user data by changing the term “unique visitors” to “users.” This is Google’s best approximation of how many people are accessing your site over a period of time. While this data isn’t perfect it’s getting more accurate all of the time and Google is getting better at tracking users across multiple devices.
  • Sessions: In another change, “visits” became “sessions.” Each time a user visits a website Google records that visit as a session. Regardless of the device, Google records each and every session, the platform and the behavior of the user while on the site (and sometimes after they leave the site, but that’s for another column!)
  • Session Duration: This is the amount of time a user spends during a visit. Google tracks individual sessions, their durations and then reports an average.

Now, about bounce rate. Bounce rate is the percentage of sessions that a user visits a single page. For instance, if 10 users visit a website and half of those visitors only visit one page then the bounce rate for that segment of users would be 50%. The question we get asked fairly often is “is this bounce rate good?” Generally, the answer is “it depends.” The fact of the matter is that there is no bounce rate percentage that is “good” or even average. Here’s why:

News websites with engaging yet ever changing content can experience radically fluctuating bounce rates. Some days they may be at 70% while other times they may be at 30%. This is true for your site as well. If a retailer publishes a blog or other unique content to their site then users may visit that page and then leave. In fact, if a particular product, offer or other page on your site is very popular and gets shared on social media you’re likely to experience a higher bounce rate site wide. This is because users coming to your site through Facebook or Twitter are more likely to be interested in a single piece of content and then they move on. About 70% of social media sessions are mobile which also adds to the likelihood of a higher bounce rate. Users on mobile devices just tend to visit fewer pages per session overall.

Several other factors can increase or reduce bounce rate as well.

  • Advertising Campaigns: Advertising campaigns, even when executed by a professional team and through high quality media can actually increase your sites bounce rate. This is because users that click on a particular offer or ad unit aren’t interested in navigating your entire website. They are clicking on your offer to get more information, get your phone number or get the address of your store. In this instance the more efficient your site the higher your bounce rate.
  • Poorly Designed Sites: Site that are poorly designed are difficult to navigate can actually have lower bounce rates than much better, well designed sites. This is a conundrum, as users aren’t getting a quality user experience yet a low bounce rate can be seen as a good thing even though your users are frustrated because they can’t find what they need and are fumbling through your site.
  • Efficiently Designed Sites: You can probably guess that a very well designed site that gets useful information in front of consumers quickly can have a high bounce rate. Combine this type of site with a targeted, efficient advertising campaign and you will likely see an increase in bounce rate.

So how do you, as the marketer interpret your bounce rate? First, it’s important to get a baseline for your site and understand what metrics are “normal” for you. What are users looking at? Where are they coming from and why are leaving? We’ll discuss this in the next column.

objects.author: deepti@thewebplant.com
objects.html_title: The Five “C’s” of Brand Awareness
objects.label: The Five “C’s” of Brand Awareness

meta.post_summary: Your brand’s logo may be the first thing that potential customers see or visualize when they hear your name or see your product. Having a strong personality behind your brand and logo is very important. Branding can be the deciding factor when a consumer is debating which product to buy. Should they buy from you or your competitor?
meta.html_title: The Five “C’s” of Brand Awareness
meta.meta_description: We do digital marketing with results that matter. From social media, web design, to digital advertising. We do it all.
meta.post_body:
Your brand’s logo may be the first thing that potential customers see or visualize when they hear your name or see your product. Having a strong personality behind your brand and logo is very important. Branding can be the deciding factor when a consumer is debating which product to buy. Should they buy from you or your competitor? 

Understanding these essential guidelines is crucial to the growth and the future "face" of your business. 

Create: Logos change lives. Many people underestimate how powerful a logo can be. Does your brand express your passion and your expertise? Are you targeting a certain niche? If so, carefully consider how you want to be recognized and what vibe you want to send. When you scale your logo down to two inches, is everything still legible? Is your logo somehow connected to your product/brand? Will your logo leave an impact on first glance? Is it easy for the consumer to remember the tagline for your business? Does your logo style match the reputation/emotion of the branding you want?  Does it translate well digitally as well as on print and other signage? These are good questions to ask yourself and your agency.

Communicate: Having a clear voice and strong statement behind your branding will make you stand out from the competition. Make sure you are communicating clearly the message  you are trying to convey. If there are misconceptions about your branding, this could cause trepidation by the potential buyer. 

Compete: Your goal is to want your consumers to be confident in your products. Your company’s strong branding and design is the extra “muscle” to push you up from the rest of the crowd.  When a happy buyer praises your products, this turns into word-of-mouth and a good recommendation for new consumers on the market. It also helps when it’s easier for the client to remember your branding or logo.

Don't go the less expensive route, as it will cost you in the long run. So many businesses decide to let their friend’s brother’s’ cousin, who took an art class in high school, design a logo for free for their company. And then become attached it. Don’t do this. It's worth hiring experts to brainstorm with you to help you achieve the perfect style and voice for your company that will prevail. 

Trust an agency to design your logo and branding. You may have ideas for it but just because you like them does not mean it is a strong logo or any relevance to your brand. In fact, it could do more harm to your business because people may be confused or just plain appalled by your branding.

Control /Continue:  It is very important to maintain your brand as well and pay attention to what your consumers are saying about you. Creating surveys to get solid feedback is a great option. As a business owner, you need to know what works and what people are more attracted to. When people are attracted to something, they will give it a second look and second thought. It will also create a subconscious reminder so that next time they are considering purchasing a product, they think of you first. You want your brand to enter into their heads first.

It’s important to understand that in the world today, you are competing in two environments. The real world and cyberspace. You need to stand out from all the noise in both.

Care: Make your business a meaningful one; caring for your customers and developing a good, honest brand pays off in the end. You must remember it's just as important for your company’s reputation to be backed by a good product and quality service. When you put an emphasis on wanting to create a good experience for your customer, you will start to stand out from the crowd and your dedicated followers will continue to increase. 

Creating an online presence and powerful branding does not happen overnight. You need to create steps and an outline of your goals with your agency first.  Branding is made up of more than just a logo and tagline. It is the face of your business, its reputation and what you keep investing into it. Positive brand recognition will reflect in the success of you business.

Compete: Your goal is to want your consumers to be confident in your products. Your company’s strong branding and design is the extra “muscle” to push you up from the rest of the crowd.  When a happy buyer praises your products, this turns into word-of-mouth and a good recommendation for new consumers on the market. It also helps when it’s easier for the client to remember your branding or logo.

Don't go the less expensive route, as it will cost you in the long run. So many businesses decide to let their friend’s brother’s’ cousin, who took an art class in high school, design a logo for free for their company. And then become attached it. Don’t do this. It's worth hiring experts to brainstorm with you to help you achieve the perfect style and voice for your company that will prevail. 

Trust an agency to design your logo and branding. You may have ideas for it but just because you like them does not mean it is a strong logo or any relevance to your brand. In fact, it could do more harm to your business because people may be confused or just plain appalled by your branding.

Control /Continue:  It is very important to maintain your brand as well and pay attention to what your consumers are saying about you. Creating surveys to get solid feedback is a great option. As a business owner, you need to know what works and what people are more attracted to. When people are attracted to something, they will give it a second look and second thought. It will also create a subconscious reminder so that next time they are considering purchasing a product, they think of you first. You want your brand to enter into their heads first.

It’s important to understand that in the world today, you are competing in two environments. The real world and cyberspace. You need to stand out from all the noise in both.

Care: Make your business a meaningful one; caring for your customers and developing a good, honest brand pays off in the end. You must remember it's just as important for your company’s reputation to be backed by a good product and quality service. When you put an emphasis on wanting to create a good experience for your customer, you will start to stand out from the crowd and your dedicated followers will continue to increase. 

Creating an online presence and powerful branding does not happen overnight. You need to create steps and an outline of your goals with your agency first.  Branding is made up of more than just a logo and tagline. It is the face of your business, its reputation and what you keep investing into it. Positive brand recognition will reflect in the success of you business.

objects.html_title: The Internet As A Brand Maker
objects.label: The Internet As A Brand Maker

meta.post_summary: The world of digital advertising is all about matching consumer behavior with relevant products and services. PPC (Pay per click) advertising, invented by Overture and perfected by Google, changed the world of marketing forever. Well-executed PPC search engine marketing does a great job of reaching customers when they’re ready to buy, or as we say in marketing, parlance at the “bottom of the funnel.”
meta.html_title: The Internet As A Brand Maker
meta.meta_description: We do digital marketing with results that matter. From social media, web design, to digital advertising. We do it all.
meta.post_body:
The world of digital advertising is all about matching consumer behavior with relevant products and services. PPC (Pay per click) advertising, invented by Overture and perfected by Google, changed the world of marketing forever. Well-executed PPC search engine marketing does a great job of reaching customers when they’re ready to buy, or as we say in marketing, parlance at the “bottom of the funnel.”

However, the Internet can also be a wonderful vehicle to use for branding and top-of-mind awareness. Much like print, radio or local TV news and entertainment websites, particularly those with in-depth local content, can reach consumers before they are ready to buy a given product. This is important for marketers because every consumer starts their shopping journey before they even realize they’re in the market. The “top of the funnel” is just as important as the bottom.

So, what are your best options for reaching consumers at the beginning and using the Internet to brand your business?

Native Advertising: native advertising has been on a rampage over the past two years. According to a survey conducted by the Association Of National Advertisers in the fourth quarter of 2014, native advertising grew 58% last year. Business Insider is projecting the segment will grow to nearly $8 billion this year, up from $4.7 billion in 2013. The projection over the next three years has native advertising reaching $21 billion. But, why all of the enthusiasm over native? Simply put: native works! Neuroscience has recently shown that native ad units are more than twice as effective in grabbing attention versus the traditional banner. The beauty of native for the advertiser lies in its flexibility. When executed properly, the marketer can frame themselves as the “mindshare” leader in their product space. Consumers at the top of the funnel are more likely to trust the marketer that has presented or sponsored authoritative content. Native advertising content must be of high quality and not a sales pitch. As is always true, high quality advertising performs best when surrounded by high quality, relevant content.  When this is the case, a native advertising piece can perform as well as some of the editorial content that it’s surrounded by.

Digital Display: Digital Display is commonly used by marketers to efficiently increase reach. For the local advertiser, news and information sites that are relevant to your customer base and provide deep, quality content are an excellent choice for positioning your brand. We routinely see that campaigns executed on local, relevant sites perform better than other types of display campaigns. Despite all of the behavioral and social targeting technologies we incorporate into many of our campaigns nothing beats a well-done display ad on a quality local site. Generally, the click-through rates we see are two to three times higher on quality local sites.

Social Media: Social Media is truly the new word of mouth. An effective social media strategy is necessary in today’s competitive local marketing environment. Like native advertising, social can help brand the advertiser and position themselves as the expert in their industry. Promoting the right content is key to the branding strategy and is easily integrated into a native advertising plan. Good native content is inherently social and engaging.

The beauty of native for the advertiser lies in its flexibility. When executed properly, the marketer can frame themselves as the “mindshare” leader in their product space. Consumers at the top of the funnel are more likely to trust the marketer that has presented or sponsored authoritative content. Native advertising content must be of high quality and not a sales pitch. As is always true, high quality advertising performs best when surrounded by high quality, relevant content.  When this is the case, a native advertising piece can perform as well as some of the editorial content that it’s surrounded by.

Digital Display: Digital Display is commonly used by marketers to efficiently increase reach. For the local advertiser, news and information sites that are relevant to your customer base and provide deep, quality content are an excellent choice for positioning your brand. We routinely see that campaigns executed on local, relevant sites perform better than other types of display campaigns. Despite all of the behavioral and social targeting technologies we incorporate into many of our campaigns nothing beats a well-done display ad on a quality local site. Generally, the click-through rates we see are two to three times higher on quality local sites.

Social Media: Social Media is truly the new word of mouth. An effective social media strategy is necessary in today’s competitive local marketing environment. Like native advertising, social can help brand the advertiser and position themselves as the expert in their industry. Promoting the right content is key to the branding strategy and is easily integrated into a native advertising plan. Good native content is inherently social and engaging.
objects.rss_summary: The world of digital advertising is all about matching consumer behavior with relevant products and services. PPC (Pay per click) advertising, invented by Overture and perfected by Google, changed the world of marketing forever. Well-executed PPC search engine marketing does a great job of reaching customers when they’re ready to buy, or as we say in marketing, parlance at the “bottom of the funnel.”
objects.title: The Internet As A Brand Maker

objects.author: deepti@thewebplant.com
objects.html_title: 7 Tips on Using Video Advertising for Your Local Business
objects.label: 7 Tips on Using Video Advertising for Your Local Business

meta.post_summary: YouTube has the potential to reach the largest percentage of the population out of any marketing medium. The latest YouTube statistics reveal that more than 1 billion unique users visit YouTube and over 6 billion hours of video are watched every month. The great thing about using video advertising is that, compared to television, it is very affordable and lets you reach a significant percentage of your target audience.
meta.html_title: 7 Tips on Using Video Advertising for Your Local Business
meta.meta_description: We do digital marketing with results that matter. From social media, web design, to digital advertising. We do it all.
meta.post_body:
YouTube has the potential to reach the largest percentage of the population out of any marketing medium. The latest YouTube statistics reveal that more than 1 billion unique users visit YouTube and over 6 billion hours of video are watched every month. The great thing about using video advertising is that, compared to television, it is very affordable and lets you reach a significant percentage of your target audience.

 

However, the two best things about video advertising are measurability and effectiveness. The old way of advertising only included estimated reach and frequency statistics but it was impossible to prove whether consumers were engaged. Now with advanced analytics, you can see who is watching your message and if they were engaged with your video. You can also run A/B testing to see if one video does better and gets more engagement. Local video advertising is extremely effective because consumers are motivated to buy after watching a video. A ReelSEO study showed that 71% of the respondents confirmed that video converts better than other content.          

We can all agree that video sets your company apart and is an effective tool for reaching your consumers. But how do you make it work for your company? Here are seven tips to get you started! 

1. Distribute and promote your video through every channel available. These include email marketing, social media channels, online ad campaigns, YouTube and your own website.

2. Make sure you are including information in your video on how your customer can find you. If you have a brick and mortar location, you might even want to include a map.

3. Don’t forget to give your video a call to action. Tell them what to do next. Do you want them to call you? Or maybe click through to your website? Or just to stop by? Make sure you give clear instructions on what the consumer should do after watching your video. 

4. Make the message personal. Add a testimonial or recommendation from a customer or have the message come from yourself of an actual employee.

5. Combine video and still images of your company location, employees, products or anything you believe will add interest and add variety to generate more engaged consumers.

6. Make your video short! It shouldn’t be longer than 30 seconds. Studies have proven that we have an attention span of about 30 seconds so keep you video to this time frame. To help with this you can do a series of videos that continues a thought or idea.

7. Remember that everybody likes to laugh so a little humor never hurts! Humor makes your company more approachable and builds a relationship with your consumer.

Your business needs video -- it sets you apart from your competition and makes you stand out online. Video allows you to tell your consumer what makes you different from your competitor. 

Video helps you start a conversation and also keeps you as part of the conversation. Here at Advocate Digital Media, we can create a video that makes you the conversation and also target it to who you want to reach online.

Your consumers are watching hours of video each day. Don’t you think you should meet them where they are?

objects.author: deepti@thewebplant.com
objects.html_title: Native Advertising = BrandSense
objects.label: Native Advertising = BrandSense

meta.post_summary: So, what is this new term ‘Native Advertising’ we have been hearing so much about? The truth is, it’s not new. Native Advertising has been around for years on popular sites like Forbes, New York Times and Buzzfeed.
meta.html_title: Native Advertising = BrandSense
meta.meta_description: We do digital marketing with results that matter. From social media, web design, to digital advertising. We do it all.
meta.post_body:
So, what is this new term ‘Native Advertising’ we have been hearing so much about? The truth is, it’s not new. Native Advertising has been around for years on popular sites like Forbes, New York Times and Buzzfeed. 

I bet you have read a native advertising article and didn’t know it. That’s because it was set up to look like an editorial piece. It’s not meant to trick or mislead but to follow the form and function of the platform on which it appears. It takes on the same form as an article written by editorial staff, but it’s actually an advertisement written to help promote the advertisers product.  It’s written to entertain, engage and/or educate the reader. 

The benefits of this type of advertisement are that consumers discover the brand.  The article topics revolve around the advertiser’s industry instead of specifically about the company. For example, a hospital might sponsor a story with the headline “5 warning signs of a heart attack” or an auto dealer might sponsor “10 signs its time to buy a new car.” This sets the advertiser up as the trusted brand name for the information that they are supplying.  The reader is more engaged and more likely to act on the information which means higher conversion rates from the advertisement. 

Advocate Digital Media has recently joined the majority of online advertising leaders in offering this type of product in the form of BrandSense. We, as well as our clients, have seen that this is a great tool in helping businesses get their message out there. Reach out to your account executive today to learn more about this exciting program that engages your business with your audience.

objects.html_title: Let Responsive Web Design Help Grow Your Mobile Traffic
objects.label: Let Responsive Web Design Help Grow Your Mobile Traffic

meta.post_summary: In 2014, mobile web traffic overtook desktop for the first time. In 2015, mobile search will overtake desktop again. Due to the explosive growth of mobile devices, web design has had to adapt. Historically, when you wanted a website, you simply developed your site to work on major desktop browsers and went about your business. If you had a mobile audience, you would build a separate mobile site where mobile users were  redirected  to. This page  was usually a simpler, less feature-rich version of your main site. For many years, this met the needs for many businesses.
meta.html_title: Let Responsive Web Design Help Grow Your Mobile Traffic
meta.meta_description: We do digital marketing with results that matter. From social media, web design, to digital advertising. We do it all.
meta.post_body:
In 2014, mobile web traffic overtook desktop for the first time. In 2015, mobile search will overtake desktop again. Due to the explosive growth of mobile devices, web design has had to adapt. Historically, when you wanted a website, you simply developed your site to work on major desktop browsers and went about your business. If you had a mobile audience, you would build a separate mobile site where mobile users were  redirected  to. This page  was usually a simpler, less feature-rich version of your main site. For many years, this met the needs for many businesses.  


However, technology keeps evolving . The increase of mobile use  means an increase in the types of devices available.  The differences between phone, tablet, and desktop are beginning to blur. Tablets are becoming more like laptops.  In the same vein, the average screen size of phones keeps increasing. The industry refers to this as convergence. It’s not just the device either. You can run Android on a phone, tablet and laptop if you choose. Apple built iOS from the same foundation that they built their desktop releases of OS X. Users are adapting to all these changes and new options. How is your business adapting?

 

These developments affect you and your business in many ways. When users come to your site on a mobile device, they want it to work like it would on their desktop. If your mobile site is missing major features available on desktop, you’re at a disadvantage. The web design industry’s response to this is responsive web design.  

Responsive web design  can make your site function the same whether you are on your phone, tablet or laptop. It does this by taking the size of the screen into account and resizing the content accordingly. This way, when I go to the Victoria Advocate’s website to read the news on my mobile phone, instead of trying  to squeeze a wide page into a narrow screen making it unreadable, the content merely reorganizes itself to fit my screen size. If I switch my phone from portrait mode to landscape, the content will again detect this change and respond accordingly. This results in a consistent experience across all devices.  


Your site’s visitors will thank you for using responsive web design. Advocate Digital Media only builds responsive websites for our clients. As technologists, we see this as the natural next step in web design. As a business owner, you will want your business and brand to be associated with a flexible modern design. It’s easy to get started. Simply reach out to your Advocate Digital Media account executive to learn about our reasonably priced WebPro packages so we can start working on your responsive site today.
meta.rss_body:
In 2014, mobile web traffic overtook desktop for the first time. In 2015, mobile search will overtake desktop again. Due to the explosive growth of mobile devices, web design has had to adapt. Historically, when you wanted a website, you simply developed your site to work on major desktop browsers and went about your business. If you had a mobile audience, you would build a separate mobile site where mobile users were  redirected  to. This page  was usually a simpler, less feature-rich version of your main site. For many years, this met the needs for many businesses.  


However, technology keeps evolving . The increase of mobile use  means an increase in the types of devices available.  The differences between phone, tablet, and desktop are beginning to blur. Tablets are becoming more like laptops.  In the same vein, the average screen size of phones keeps increasing. The industry refers to this as convergence. It’s not just the device either. You can run Android on a phone, tablet and laptop if you choose. Apple built iOS from the same foundation that they built their desktop releases of OS X. Users are adapting to all these changes and new options. How is your business adapting?

 

These developments affect you and your business in many ways. When users come to your site on a mobile device, they want it to work like it would on their desktop. If your mobile site is missing major features available on desktop, you’re at a disadvantage. The web design industry’s response to this is responsive web design.  

Responsive web design  can make your site function the same whether you are on your phone, tablet or laptop. It does this by taking the size of the screen into account and resizing the content accordingly. This way, when I go to the Victoria Advocate’s website to read the news on my mobile phone, instead of trying  to squeeze a wide page into a narrow screen making it unreadable, the content merely reorganizes itself to fit my screen size. If I switch my phone from portrait mode to landscape, the content will again detect this change and respond accordingly. This results in a consistent experience across all devices.  


Your site’s visitors will thank you for using responsive web design. Advocate Digital Media only builds responsive websites for our clients. As technologists, we see this as the natural next step in web design. As a business owner, you will want your business and brand to be associated with a flexible modern design. It’s easy to get started. Simply reach out to your Advocate Digital Media account executive to learn about our reasonably priced WebPro packages so we can start working on your responsive site today.

objects.html_title: ADM Returns to JCK Show in Las Vegas
objects.label: ADM Returns to JCK Show in Las Vegas

meta.post_summary: After a successful premiere at JCK Las Vegas 2014, Advocate Digital Media is pleased to announce they will return to the 2015 show at booth L125. JCK is the leading international jewelry event in North America where industry leaders gather to see the latest trends by domestic and international designers, as well as network and attend educational sessions. Advocate Digital Media will visit with jewelry leaders from around the world about their their suite of industry-leading digital products and services, as well as their product JewelBox. JewelBox jewelry sites offer jewelry store owners an effortless way to host their latest stunning pieces online and easily manage the e-commerce, as well as encourage the social sharing of their inventory across multiple social media sites.
meta.html_title: ADM Returns to JCK Show in Las Vegas
meta.meta_description: We do digital marketing with results that matter. From social media, web design, to digital advertising. We do it all.
meta.post_body:
After a successful premiere at JCK Las Vegas 2014, Advocate Digital Media is pleased to announce they will return to the 2015 show at booth L125. JCK is the leading international jewelry event in North America where industry leaders gather to see the latest trends by domestic and international designers, as well as network and attend educational sessions. Advocate Digital Media will visit with jewelry leaders from around the world about their their suite of industry-leading digital products and services, as well as their product JewelBox. JewelBox jewelry sites offer jewelry store owners an effortless way to host their latest stunning pieces online and easily manage the e-commerce, as well as encourage the social sharing of their inventory across multiple social media sites.

With JewelBox’s robust promotional components, jewelry leaders will find improved search results thanks to industry leading search engine optimization, as well as social media integration, lead generation and customer relationship tools. These tools even include consumers’ ability to set up personal wish lists and shopping tools where they can easily request more information on specific pieces. All of this is done through responsive design, making sure the users experience across multiple devices is first-rate.

”Since many of today’s consumers are turning first to their tablets and mobile devices to shop online, we built JewelBox to elegantly transition from the consumers’ various points of entry to the sites. JewelBox sites work seamlessly across multiple platforms and we are using leading SEO to generate traffic to help our customers to be found on search engines, “said Jason Homes, Advocate Digital Media General Manager.

Learn more about JewelBox today by visiting www.jewelboxmedia.com. 

Advocate Digital Media is a full service digital agency offering targeted digital campaigns, responsive website design and optimization, industry leading search engine strategies and social media plans for a variety of clients. Learn more at www.AdvocateDigitalMedia.com

objects.author: deepti@thewebplant.com
objects.html_title: Advanced Audience Targeting – How it Helped Me and How it Can Help Your Business
objects.label: Advanced Audience Targeting – How it Helped Me and How it Can Help Your Business

meta.post_summary: 23 years. That number stuns me. It’s been 23 years since human kind began its love affair with the World Wide Web.  In that time, the way we use the Internet has changed and businesses need to make sure that they are adjusting to those changes.
meta.html_title: Advanced Audience Targeting – How it Helped Me and How it Can Help Your Business
meta.meta_description: We do digital marketing with results that matter. From social media, web design, to digital advertising. We do it all.
meta.post_body:
23 years. That number stuns me. It’s been 23 years since human kind began its love affair with the World Wide Web.  In that time, the way we use the Internet has changed and businesses need to make sure that they are adjusting to those changes.  

Early content on the web was sparse. There wasn’t much to compete for our attention. Today, there is so much content that the average American spends over 120 hours per month on the Internet.  We spend more time on the Internet than we do on basically any other activity in our daily lives. This makes the Internet a highly coveted place to engage with potential customers.  This is where targeted display (advanced audience targeting) comes into play. This is one of the most effective ways to get the right ad in front of the right person at the right time, as they spend time in their favorite place… searching and browsing the Internet. 

The best way to explain this sophisticated type of advertising is to recount one of my personal Internet experiences.  Earlier this month, I was planning a quick get away to Austin to celebrate my boyfriend’s birthday. I researched hotels, craft breweries, restaurants and live music venues.  As I enjoyed my time on the Internet researching all the great fun we were going to have in Austin, I started to notice something. Ads were being put in front of me that pertained to my research. Doubletree Hotel, American Express Travel Card, an Austin excursion company, and TravelTex.com were a few.  In real time, the Internet was delivering ads to me that pertained to my immediate needs and searches. This is a clear example of advanced audience targeting.   

With advanced audience targeting, you can target potential customers in a multitude of ways. You can target them geographically based on where they live. You can target them based on the content they are reading, listening or watching on the Internet. You can target them based on the keywords they are typing into search engines and websites. And you can target customers that have already visited your website. If that wasn’t sophisticated enough, you can blend all of these targeting strategies. That’s the beauty. Every business’s target customer is going to be different. In fact, the type of customer you are looking for today might be different next month. With targeted advertising, you can change your message and the type of customer you need to reach as your needs change. 

My Austin trip was a huge success.  We stayed at a nice place on 4th Street. Enjoyed a great craft beer tour (which I found through a targeted ad), dined on some authentic Irish fare, and rocked out to some Stout Irish Rock with the Blaggards (one of his favorite bands).  And remember that TravelTex.com ad that targeted me? Well, I clicked it. And now I’m using it to plan another getaway. This time to Fredericksburg! 

Reach out to your account executive today to learn how affordable and extremely effective advanced audience targeting can be for your business. Visit www.advocatedigital.com or call 1-855-322-3355.

Early content on the web was sparse. There wasn’t much to compete for our attention. Today, there is so much content that the average American spends over 120 hours per month on the Internet.  We spend more time on the Internet than we do on basically any other activity in our daily lives. This makes the Internet a highly coveted place to engage with potential customers.  This is where targeted display (advanced audience targeting) comes into play. This is one of the most effective ways to get the right ad in front of the right person at the right time, as they spend time in their favorite place… searching and browsing the Internet. 

The best way to explain this sophisticated type of advertising is to recount one of my personal Internet experiences.  Earlier this month, I was planning a quick get away to Austin to celebrate my boyfriend’s birthday. I researched hotels, craft breweries, restaurants and live music venues.  As I enjoyed my time on the Internet researching all the great fun we were going to have in Austin, I started to notice something. Ads were being put in front of me that pertained to my research. Doubletree Hotel, American Express Travel Card, an Austin excursion company, and TravelTex.com were a few.  In real time, the Internet was delivering ads to me that pertained to my immediate needs and searches. This is a clear example of advanced audience targeting.   

With advanced audience targeting, you can target potential customers in a multitude of ways. You can target them geographically based on where they live. You can target them based on the content they are reading, listening or watching on the Internet. You can target them based on the keywords they are typing into search engines and websites. And you can target customers that have already visited your website. If that wasn’t sophisticated enough, you can blend all of these targeting strategies. That’s the beauty. Every business’s target customer is going to be different. In fact, the type of customer you are looking for today might be different next month. With targeted advertising, you can change your message and the type of customer you need to reach as your needs change. 

My Austin trip was a huge success.  We stayed at a nice place on 4th Street. Enjoyed a great craft beer tour (which I found through a targeted ad), dined on some authentic Irish fare, and rocked out to some Stout Irish Rock with the Blaggards (one of his favorite bands).  And remember that TravelTex.com ad that targeted me? Well, I clicked it. And now I’m using it to plan another getaway. This time to Fredericksburg! 

Reach out to your account executive today to learn how affordable and extremely effective advanced audience targeting can be for your business. Visit www.advocatedigital.com or call 1-855-322-3355.

objects.html_title: Advocate Digital Media Presents 2015 Business Solutions Conference
objects.label: Advocate Digital Media Presents 2015 Business Solutions Conference

meta.post_summary: Longview full service agency Advocate Digital Media is proud to be the presenting sponsor of the Longview Chamber’s Business Solutions Conference 2015.
meta.html_title: Advocate Digital Media Presents 2015 Business Solutions Conference
meta.meta_description: We do digital marketing with results that matter. From social media, web design, to digital advertising. We do it all.
meta.post_body:
Longview full service agency Advocate Digital Media is proud to be the presenting sponsor of the Longview Chamber’s Business Solutions Conference 2015. 

The conference is scheduled for May 5 at the Maude Cobb Convention Center. 

East Texas industry leaders are invited to attend to gain the latest insights, build lasting connections and take advantage of the great educational sessions. 

“When we met with the Longview Chamber of Commerce to discuss the vision for the 2015 event, we knew this was a unique opportunity to partner to help further our mission of educating the business community, particularly on the latest trends and developments in advertising and digital marketing, “ Alexander Gould, Digital Sales Director for Advocate Digital Media, said. 

Attendees for the one-day event are invited begin arriving at 8:30 a.m. for the first round of sessions and to visit the expo floor. There are four main areas of educational sessions: sales & marketing, leadership & management, accounting & benefits and entrepreneurship. 

“From social media to preparing a business plan, these 30 minute sessions will be packed with powerful takeaways that business owners can implement immediately, “ Gould said. 

Each session is $25 and requires advanced registration. Gould will be presenting “Social Media – One Piece to the Digital Puzzle” at 8:30 a.m. in the Sales and Marketing track. 

A highlight of the event will be the keynote speaker, Brian Brandt, presenting “A Learner for Life.” He’ll prescribe three key areas that every leader needs to focus on for their lifetime. The keynote luncheon will be held from 11:30 to 1:00 p.m. and cost to attend is $25. 

A full day package, which includes three educational sessions as well as the luncheon, is $85. Learn more and register now to attend at LongviewChamber.com/BSC or call 903-237-4000. 

“At Advocate Digital Media, we focus on staying ahead of the shifting media landscape and responding to emerging trends. By partnering and presenting this conference, we feel we are sharing the wealth of this information not only with our clients, but also to all business owners in the area that can greatly benefit,“ Gould said.

objects.html_title: Google: Get Mobile Or Get off The Internet
objects.label: Google: Get Mobile Or Get off The Internet

meta.post_summary: Search engines still drive the majority of traffic to sites all over the Internet.  And when you think search you absolutely, positively must think Google. According to comScore, Google’s search market share sits at around 67% on desktop and an astounding 83.3% on mobile. This means that more than 8 out of 10 smartphone users that find your business website through search are getting there through Google.
meta.html_title: Google: Get Mobile Or Get off The Internet
meta.meta_description: We do digital marketing with results that matter. From social media, web design, to digital advertising. We do it all.
meta.post_body:
Search engines still drive the majority of traffic to sites all over the Internet.  And when you think search you absolutely, positively must think Google. According to comScore, Google’s search market share sits at around 67% on desktop and an astounding 83.3% on mobile. This means that more than 8 out of 10 smartphone users that find your business website through search are getting there through Google.

As you can imagine, being ignored by Google would be very bad for business. However, that’s exactly what will be happening to millions of sites that Google deems unworthy beginning April 21. What makes your site “unworthy”? No mobile version or properly implemented responsive design.

The February 26 entry on Google’s official Webmaster Central Blog stated that beginning April 21 they will be expanding the use of “mobile-friendliness” as a ranking signal. As understated as this sounds, this is huge news for sites that aren’t mobile friendly. If your site isn’t then you can expect your search traffic to significantly drop and for those redirect consumers to end up on other sites. 

To be fair, Google has been encouraging site owners to at least serve up a mobile version of their site for years. In fact, Google declared responsive design as an “industry best practice” nearly two years ago. So this shouldn’t be a shock. 

Over 30% of Google’s business is now mobile and the trend isn’t reversing. Overall Internet use is above this and on content sites desktop traffic has generally been eclipsed by mobile. This change makes sense in a “post PC” world.

What To Do Now

• If you aren’t sure if Google considers your site as “mobile friendly” then your first step is to verify this status. You can do that here: https://www.google.com/webmasters/tools/mobile-friendly/

• If your worst fears are confirmed and your site isn’t seen as mobile friendly then it’s time to take action. Should you completely redesign or can you make a few tweaks? Are you equipped to take this on or should you hire a professional firm?

• After your site is either redesigned or modified for mobile make sure you retest your site using Google’s tool! Even sites that are supposedly responsive or optimized for mobile can include errors not noticed by humans.

Of course, the most important aspect of your site is usability. Even though search engines are currently sending traffic to your site, if your site isn’t optimized for mobile already then your audience is suffering.

--

Jason Holmes is the General Manager of Advocate Digital Media. He welcomes questions and column ideas. jtholmes@advocatedigital.com

If your site isn’t then you can expect your search traffic to significantly drop and for those redirect consumers to end up on other sites. 

To be fair, Google has been encouraging site owners to at least serve up a mobile version of their site for years. In fact, Google declared responsive design as an “industry best practice” nearly two years ago. So this shouldn’t be a shock. 

Over 30% of Google’s business is now mobile and the trend isn’t reversing. Overall Internet use is above this and on content sites desktop traffic has generally been eclipsed by mobile. This change makes sense in a “post PC” world.

What To Do Now

• If you aren’t sure if Google considers your site as “mobile friendly” then your first step is to verify this status. You can do that here: https://www.google.com/webmasters/tools/mobile-friendly/

• If your worst fears are confirmed and your site isn’t seen as mobile friendly then it’s time to take action. Should you completely redesign or can you make a few tweaks? Are you equipped to take this on or should you hire a professional firm?

• After your site is either redesigned or modified for mobile make sure you retest your site using Google’s tool! Even sites that are supposedly responsive or optimized for mobile can include errors not noticed by humans.

Of course, the most important aspect of your site is usability. Even though search engines are currently sending traffic to your site, if your site isn’t optimized for mobile already then your audience is suffering.

--

Jason Holmes is the General Manager of Advocate Digital Media. He welcomes questions and column ideas. jtholmes@advocatedigital.com

Search engines still drive the majority of traffic to sites all over the Internet.  And when you think search you absolutely, positively must think Google. According to comScore, Google’s search market share sits at around 67% on desktop and an astounding 83.3% on mobile. This means that more than 8 out of 10 smartphone users that find your business website through search are getting there through Google.

As you can imagine, being ignored by Google would be very bad for business. However, that’s exactly what will be happening to millions of sites that Google deems unworthy beginning April 21. What makes your site “unworthy”? No mobile version or properly implemented responsive design.

What To Do Now

• If you aren’t sure if Google considers your site as “mobile friendly” then your first step is to verify this status. You can do that here: https://www.google.com/webmasters/tools/mobile-friendly/

• If your worst fears are confirmed and your site isn’t seen as mobile friendly then it’s time to take action. Should you completely redesign or can you make a few tweaks? Are you equipped to take this on or should you hire a professional firm?

• After your site is either redesigned or modified for mobile make sure you retest your site using Google’s tool! Even sites that are supposedly responsive or optimized for mobile can include errors not noticed by humans.

Of course, the most important aspect of your site is usability. Even though search engines are currently sending traffic to your site, if your site isn’t optimized for mobile already then your audience is suffering.

objects.html_title: Working with a Digital Advertising Agency
objects.label: Working with a Digital Advertising Agency

meta.post_summary: By Alexis Busselman, Lead Account Executive, Advocate Digital Media
meta.html_title: Working with a Digital Advertising Agency
meta.meta_description: We do digital marketing with results that matter. From social media, web design, to digital advertising. We do it all.
meta.post_body:
By Alexis Busselman, Lead Account Executive, Advocate Digital Media

Efficient advertising and marketing campaigns can make a tremendous impact in the success of a company. Advertising can often be an overwhelming task for a business owner to tackle, with many different media options and uncertainties of the most effective outlet to reach their target audience. Working with an advertising agency can provide guidance when it comes to budgeting and media buying, it also will ensure a consistent and professional branding across all medias. 

Advocate Digital Media is a full-service advertising agency with a digital focus. As the media landscape continues to see a shift from traditional advertising to digital, it is important that the advertising agency that a business is working with is familiar with the vast array of digital advertising services available. While ADM can serve as your local go-to for logo design, websites, advanced targeting, Google AdWords, YouTube Truview, Pandora, Hulu and other digital avenues, we also have the ability to assist with other media buys. An advertising agency can serve as a “gatekeeper” between you and the other media companies; negotiating rates, ad placement and often having the inside scoop when it comes to specials or sponsorship opportunities. Once the buy is placed by your advertising agency, you can be confident that the message being presented is consistent with the other campaigns that are running simultaneously. 

One of the biggest challenges when it comes to media planning is establishing a budget and planning on which media to spend the dollars that are available. How do you know what is going to be most effective, reach your target audience or leave the most memorable impression? ADM invests in data called Compass from Borell Associates – a highly regarded industry research company. This data allows us to strategically analyze advertising spending patterns and forecast potential changes in specific geographic areas and with different industries. In turn, ADM is able to provide educated budget suggestions to our agency customers. 

An advertising agency should be seen an extension of your current staff. Your agency is more than just one person; it is a full team working toward the same goal as you – to drive more people through your door. When working with an advertising agency, you should feel confident that your dedicated team is providing the best feedback and advise for your advertising and marketing campaigns. The advertising budget should be visited regularly and new media presentations always considered, ensuring that potential opportunities aren’t missed. 

Give us a call today to learn more about our agency services. And, visit our site at www.advocatedigital.com and view our portfolio to see some examples of work we’ve done for our clients.

objects.author: deepti@thewebplant.com
objects.html_title: Disruptive Innovation In Action
objects.label: Disruptive Innovation In Action

meta.post_summary: This week, a centuries old industry was introduced to the concept of disruptive innovation and most companies didn’t really take notice. The company that just enjoyed the most profitable quarter in history – as in ever in the history of business – just took aim at one of the oldest most profitable industries in the world. Apple has simultaneously aimed a product line at both the high end of the market and at the entry-level through it’s pricing scheme but also through style. I am of course talking about the Apple Watch.
meta.html_title: Disruptive Innovation In Action
meta.meta_description: We do digital marketing with results that matter. From social media, web design, to digital advertising. We do it all.
meta.post_body:
This week, a centuries old industry was introduced to the concept of disruptive innovation and most companies didn’t really take notice. The company that just enjoyed the most profitable quarter in history – as in ever in the history of business – just took aim at one of the oldest most profitable industries in the world. Apple has simultaneously aimed a product line at both the high end of the market and at the entry-level through it’s pricing scheme but also through style. I am of course talking about the Apple Watch.

At Apple’s live event on Monday, the company released far more details about its upcoming watch including its release date next month and a slew of model options. The entry-level “Watch Sport” starts at $349 while the “Watch Edition” ranges in price from $10,000 to $17,000. In my estimation, from a price perspective, the entry-level product is poised to compete with Citizen or Bulova lineups while the high end product is making a run at the mid-level Rolex or Omega shopper. The entry and mid-level products in the lineup are obviously being positioned as functional yet attractive smart watches while Apple has simultaneously set the expectation that luxury should also be supremely functional. In my opinion, this strategy is brilliant.

The most interesting thing to me about this disruption is the reaction from within the luxury watch community.

The common comment is that “they won’t hold their value like a luxury Swiss watch” or similar. In fact, one prominent industry executive was quoted as saying that the Apple Watch is “condemned to be obsolete” and that it “cannot compete with any prestigious brand.”

Not everyone has been as dismissive. In an interview with Bloomberg Swatch, co-inventor Elmar Mock predicted that “Apple will succeed quickly” and that an “Ice Age is coming” for the Swiss watch industry.

Only time will tell how successful the Apple watch will be at unseating the top luxury brands. The biggest factor in Apple’s favor may be the scarcity of “wrist real-estate.” Most people will only wear one watch at a time and as things get more convenient to do with your smart watch then the likelihood of choosing to wear a smart watch increases.

Mechanical luxury watches are amazingly accurate, beautiful products. However, I don’t believe this industry has faced anything like this before. Being able to unlock your hotel room, display your boarding pass and monitor your vitals all from your wrist may be a game changer.

--

About: Jason Holmes is the General Manager of Advocate Digital Media, a sister company to The Victoria Advocate that focuses on digital marketing. He welcomes questions and column ideas. jtholmes@advocatedigital.com

Only time will tell how successful the Apple watch will be at unseating the top luxury brands. The biggest factor in Apple’s favor may be the scarcity of “wrist real-estate.” Most people will only wear one watch at a time and as things get more convenient to do with your smart watch then the likelihood of choosing to wear a smart watch increases.

Mechanical luxury watches are amazingly accurate, beautiful products. However, I don’t believe this industry has faced anything like this before. Being able to unlock your hotel room, display your boarding pass and monitor your vitals all from your wrist may be a game changer.

--

About: Jason Holmes is the General Manager of Advocate Digital Media, a sister company to The Victoria Advocate that focuses on digital marketing. He welcomes questions and column ideas. jtholmes@advocatedigital.com

objects.rss_body:
This week, a centuries old industry was introduced to the concept of disruptive innovation and most companies didn’t really take notice. The company that just enjoyed the most profitable quarter in history – as in ever in the history of business – just took aim at one of the oldest most profitable industries in the world. Apple has simultaneously aimed a product line at both the high end of the market and at the entry-level through it’s pricing scheme but also through style. I am of course talking about the Apple Watch.

At Apple’s live event on Monday, the company released far more details about its upcoming watch including its release date next month and a slew of model options. The entry-level “Watch Sport” starts at $349 while the “Watch Edition” ranges in price from $10,000 to $17,000. In my estimation, from a price perspective, the entry-level product is poised to compete with Citizen or Bulova lineups while the high end product is making a run at the mid-level Rolex or Omega shopper. The entry and mid-level products in the lineup are obviously being positioned as functional yet attractive smart watches while Apple has simultaneously set the expectation that luxury should also be supremely functional. In my opinion, this strategy is brilliant.

The most interesting thing to me about this disruption is the reaction from within the luxury watch community.

The common comment is that “they won’t hold their value like a luxury Swiss watch” or similar. In fact, one prominent industry executive was quoted as saying that the Apple Watch is “condemned to be obsolete” and that it “cannot compete with any prestigious brand.”

Not everyone has been as dismissive. In an interview with Bloomberg Swatch, co-inventor Elmar Mock predicted that “Apple will succeed quickly” and that an “Ice Age is coming” for the Swiss watch industry.

Only time will tell how successful the Apple watch will be at unseating the top luxury brands. The biggest factor in Apple’s favor may be the scarcity of “wrist real-estate.” Most people will only wear one watch at a time and as things get more convenient to do with your smart watch then the likelihood of choosing to wear a smart watch increases.

Mechanical luxury watches are amazingly accurate, beautiful products. However, I don’t believe this industry has faced anything like this before. Being able to unlock your hotel room, display your boarding pass and monitor your vitals all from your wrist may be a game changer.

--

I am of course talking about the Apple Watch.

objects.label: Advocate Digital Media Hosts Google Partner Event on Video Advertising

meta.post_summary: Advocate Digital Media, a full service digital agency and Google Partner, will host a Google Partner Connect livestream event presented by Google experts over the lunch hour on Wednesday, March 25 at the Longview News-Journal and on Thursday, March 26 at the Victoria Country Club. The topic for this exclusive event will be branding and strategy for digital video advertising. Those business owners wishing to attend this educational event and benefit are asked to RSVP to info@advocatedigital.com.
meta.html_title: Advocate Digital Media Hosts Google Partner Event on Video Advertising
meta.meta_description: We do digital marketing with results that matter. From social media, web design, to digital advertising. We do it all.
meta.post_body:
Advocate Digital Media, a full service digital agency and Google Partner, will host a Google Partner Connect livestream event presented by Google experts over the lunch hour on Wednesday, March 25 at the Longview News-Journal and on Thursday, March 26 at the Victoria Country Club. The topic for this exclusive event will be branding and strategy for digital video advertising. Those business owners wishing to attend this educational event and benefit are asked to RSVP to info@advocatedigital.com. 

Presenter Suzie Reider, managing director for Brand Solutions, will share insights about the YouTube audience and content strategy to help businesses connect with customers in a deep and meaningful ways. Mark McMaster, global product lead for YouTube Advertising, will walk through the brass tactics of YouTube video advertising for businesses and share real life examples. 

“This is a great opportunity for local business owners to stay ahead of the curve and hear about emerging video advertising trends directly from national Google Partners as well as Advocate Digital Media’s local Google Partner experts, “ said Jason Holmes, general manager for Advocate Digital Media. Being a certified Google Partner means that Google trusts Advocate Digital Media, who has demonstrated proven success using industry best practices to provide quality digital marketing services. 

Those wishing to attend the Google Partner Connect event on March 25 or 26 are asked to RSVP no later than Monday, March 23 by calling 361-580-6553 or email info@advocatedigital.com.

 

Advocate Digital Media is a full service digital advertising agency and Google partner offering targeted digital campaigns, responsive website design and optimization, industry leading search engine strategies and social media plans for a variety of clients. The agency handles all forms of advertising and marketing, including branding, creative design, video production, outdoor, online, TV, radio, and print media planning and buying. Learn more at www.AdvocateDigitalMedia.com

objects.html_title: Creative Does Matter
objects.label: Creative Does Matter

meta.post_summary: This column generally includes a lot of mind-numbing stats that tell a story. However, the Internet is human and humans are social. This was evident during the Super Bowl; the reactions on Twitter and Facebook to plays on the field were swift and ubiquitous. Likewise, the reactions to the season’s most anticipated commercials were also immediate and judgmental.
meta.html_title: Creative Does Matter
meta.meta_description: We do digital marketing with results that matter. From social media, web design, to digital advertising. We do it all.
meta.post_body:
This column generally includes a lot of mind-numbing stats that tell a story. However, the Internet is human and humans are social. This was evident during the Super Bowl; the reactions on Twitter and Facebook to plays on the field were swift and ubiquitous. Likewise, the reactions to the season’s most anticipated commercials were also immediate and judgmental.

http://youtu.be/dKUy-tfrIHY

One commercial, the Nationwide Insurance spot, featured a somber tone intended to invoke an emotional reaction. If you missed the commercial, it was unusually sad for a Super Bowl spot. It featured a young boy around seven years old recounting all of the things he’ll never do like “get cooties” or “learn to fly.” The spot has a happy feeling and utilizes fantasy related imagery throughout. It isn’t until the end that we learn the boy couldn’t do any of these things because he died from an accident. The call to action was to #makesafehappen. It’s a powerful spot seen by the largest television audience in history but it was the wrong place for a depressing ad.

The Internet took offense to the spot with 64% of tweets being negative. Tweets like:

“Thanks Nationwide. We were all in danger of having a fun Sunday.”

“Nationwide: Think of us as the Dead Kid Company”

"Hope you guys are having a great day. Did you know your kid is probably gonna die soon? Enjoy your nachos & funeral planning!" - Nationwide

The spot didn’t “start a conversation” as Nationwide claimed was the intent in its apology.

Of course, the Internet has a sense of humor and within minutes Internet memes were using the kid from the commercial to say things like “I would have run it with Lynch but I died.”

The point is that as a brand owner, large or small, you need to be certain your creative matches the audience and is memorable for the right reasons. Nationwide’s spot will be remembered but for all the wrong reasons. Millions wasted and incalculable damage to the brand.

The mistake is compounded by the fact that this is one of the few remaining opportunities to reach a live audience on traditional television. A new study out just this month by Nomura shows a one-year decline in traditional television viewing of 12% while digital competitors like Hulu, Amazon and other streaming services showed double digital growth.

National advertisers are generally the ones that push it too far and miss the mark like this example because of their willingness to roll the dice. Local businesses generally employ easily forgettable creative that is “brand safe” yet still a waste. The key is creating something memorable that connects with your local audience and reaches them where and when they are receptive to your message.

If your marketing efforts haven’t really changed in decades or you’re not sure how to reach today’s mobile and social consumer then make sure you work with someone that can help you update your approach while protecting your brand.

Likewise, the reactions to the season’s most anticipated commercials were also immediate and judgmental.

objects.rss_body:
This column generally includes a lot of mind-numbing stats that tell a story. However, the Internet is human and humans are social. This was evident during the Super Bowl; the reactions on Twitter and Facebook to plays on the field were swift and ubiquitous. Likewise, the reactions to the season’s most anticipated commercials were also immediate and judgmental.

http://youtu.be/dKUy-tfrIHY

One commercial, the Nationwide Insurance spot, featured a somber tone intended to invoke an emotional reaction. If you missed the commercial, it was unusually sad for a Super Bowl spot. It featured a young boy around seven years old recounting all of the things he’ll never do like “get cooties” or “learn to fly.” The spot has a happy feeling and utilizes fantasy related imagery throughout. It isn’t until the end that we learn the boy couldn’t do any of these things because he died from an accident. The call to action was to #makesafehappen. It’s a powerful spot seen by the largest television audience in history but it was the wrong place for a depressing ad.

The Internet took offense to the spot with 64% of tweets being negative. Tweets like:

“Thanks Nationwide. We were all in danger of having a fun Sunday.”

“Nationwide: Think of us as the Dead Kid Company”

"Hope you guys are having a great day. Did you know your kid is probably gonna die soon? Enjoy your nachos & funeral planning!" - Nationwide

The spot didn’t “start a conversation” as Nationwide claimed was the intent in its apology.

Of course, the Internet has a sense of humor and within minutes Internet memes were using the kid from the commercial to say things like “I would have run it with Lynch but I died.”

The point is that as a brand owner, large or small, you need to be certain your creative matches the audience and is memorable for the right reasons. Nationwide’s spot will be remembered but for all the wrong reasons. Millions wasted and incalculable damage to the brand.

The mistake is compounded by the fact that this is one of the few remaining opportunities to reach a live audience on traditional television. A new study out just this month by Nomura shows a one-year decline in traditional television viewing of 12% while digital competitors like Hulu, Amazon and other streaming services showed double digital growth.

National advertisers are generally the ones that push it too far and miss the mark like this example because of their willingness to roll the dice. Local businesses generally employ easily forgettable creative that is “brand safe” yet still a waste. The key is creating something memorable that connects with your local audience and reaches them where and when they are receptive to your message.

If your marketing efforts haven’t really changed in decades or you’re not sure how to reach today’s mobile and social consumer then make sure you work with someone that can help you update your approach while protecting your brand.

objects.title: Creative Does Matter

meta.post_summary: Advocate Digital Media, a full service digital agency and Google Partner, will host a Google Partner Connect livestream event presented by Google experts on Wednesday, February 11 during the lunch hour at The Sendera in Victoria, TX and at the Longview News-Journal in Longview, TX. Those business owners wishing to attend this educational event and benefit are asked to RSVP to 361-580-6553.
meta.html_title: Advocate Digital Media Hosts Google Partner Event
meta.meta_description: We do digital marketing with results that matter. From social media, web design, to digital advertising. We do it all.
meta.post_body:
Advocate Digital Media, a full service digital agency and Google Partner, will host a Google Partner Connect livestream event presented by Google experts on Wednesday, February 11 during the lunch hour at The Sendera in Victoria, TX and at the Longview News-Journal in Longview, TX. Those business owners wishing to attend this educational event and benefit are asked to RSVP to 361-580-6553.

Presenters include Todd Rowe, managing director for Global Channel Sales, and Fred Vallaeys, a Google AdWords evangelist. Rowe will discuss how small businesses can differentiate themselves from their competitors through digital marketing. Vallaeys will cover how small businesses can navigate the web and expand their online presence through smarter insights.

“This is a great opportunity for local business owners to stay ahead of the curve and hear about emerging trends directly from national Google Partners as well as Advocate Digital Media’s local Google Partner experts, “ said Jason Holmes, general manager for Advocate Digital Media. Being a certified Google Partner means that Google trusts Advocate Digital Media, who has demonstrated proven success using industry best practices to provide high quality digital marketing services.

Those wishing to attend the Google Partner Connect event on February 11 are asked to RSVP no later than Tuesday, Feb. 10 by noon by calling 361-580-6553.
