objects.html_title: December is Digital
objects.label: December is Digital

meta.post_summary: Nationally, Black Friday sales were down 11% this year while Cyber Monday sales rose 8%, according to Business Insider. Sadly, many local merchants just aren’t ready to compete with big box stores and online retailers like Amazon and Wal-Mart.
meta.html_title: December is Digital
meta.meta_description: We do digital marketing with results that matter. From social media, web design, to digital advertising. We do it all.
meta.post_body:
Nationally, Black Friday sales were down 11% this year while Cyber Monday sales rose 8%, according to Business Insider. Sadly, many local merchants just aren’t ready to compete with big box stores and online retailers like Amazon and Wal-Mart.

Many local consumer--facing businesses are under the impression that they’re stuck in a disadvantaged position when trying to appeal to the same customers as their online counterparts. This line of thinking is dangerous for local businesses. Locally owned stores have many advantages that they need to capitalize on if they plan to compete. However, they have to think about where the people they’re trying to reach are spending most of their time. The answer these days is online and in particularly on their mobile devices.

Consider this: 64% of Black Friday shoppers researched in-store Black Friday deals online before going shopping. This is more than 10 times the number of people that tuned in to the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade and NFL football on Thanksgiving Day.

How did your store compete? Did they find your products and services or your competitors? These are shoppers ready to buy in the physical world. They want to view and touch the merchandise before taking it home. They want to feel like they’re getting a good deal and enjoy the experience. But they want a preview online before they commit and drive to your store.

In the weeks leading up to Black Friday, a few local merchants targeted me (and probably you) online. These local advertising messages always stand out to me when they’re well targeted and relevant.

If you’ve missed out so far, where do you start? Over the past year this space has been used to help you improve your digital presence and build awareness for your brand, products and services utilizing tactics that touch on social media, search, targeted display, mobile and the red hot category of digital video. Obviously, if you haven’t taken action up to this point then it hasn’t been a priority. I’d encourage you not to make the same mistake in 2015.

As a recap, here are my recommended steps to get started:

  1.  Evaluate your web presence. This means your website, social network profiles and business directory listings. Is this basic information accurate? Business hours, addresses, website links, specials, etc.  With this region growing so fast there are literally thousands of people new to the region. The Internet is generally the number one source for information when relocating.
  2.  Repeat step one on a mobile device. This can be eye opening. If you consider that more than 40% of search traffic on Google, Yahoo! and Bing is now mobile and that 50% of that traffic has local intent – meaning that local people are searching for local businesses, products and services it’s incumbent on the local business owner to be ready for mobile. A staggering 30% of all Black Friday purchases last week were made on mobile.
  3. Evaluate your competition from the viewpoint of a consumer online. If you’re competing with national companies or large regional players it may seem daunting to take that fight online. However, you have advantages over big box stores. You likely highlight those advantages to your customer base everyday in your store or in your marketing message. Get that message out through digital means on social networks and targeted digital advertising vehicles.
  4. Educate yourself. Find local digital marketing experts and ask them tough questions, especially if they’re asking you to spend money with them. There are no dumb questions in the realm of digital advertising and you should only spend money on products that you understand. Ask questions until you have a working understanding of what you’re buying.

Jason Holmes is the General Manager of Advocate Digital Media, a sister company to The Victoria Advocate that focuses on digital marketing. He welcomes questions and column ideas. jtholmes@advocatedigital.com

There are no dumb questions in the realm of digital advertising and you should only spend money on products that you understand. Ask questions until you have a working understanding of what you’re buying.

Jason Holmes is the General Manager of Advocate Digital Media, a sister company to The Victoria Advocate that focuses on digital marketing. He welcomes questions and column ideas. jtholmes@advocatedigital.com
objects.rss_summary: Nationally, Black Friday sales were down 11% this year while Cyber Monday sales rose 8%, according to Business Insider. Sadly, many local merchants just aren’t ready to compete with big box stores and online retailers like Amazon and Wal-Mart.

meta.html_title: Advocate Digital Media Digital Sales Director Recognized by Local Media Association
meta.meta_description: We do digital marketing with results that matter. From social media, web design, to digital advertising. We do it all.
meta.post_body:
Jennifer Love, digital sales director for Advocate Digital Media, was recently awarded second place by the Local Media Association in their 2014 Advertising & Promotions Contest for “Digital Sales Manager of the Year.” Love faced competition from top digital sales leaders from around the country. In her nomination letter, ADM’s general manager Jason Holmes wrote, “ Jennifer’s confident approach to building her sales team has helped Advocate Digital Media to become more than a ‘digital agency’ in Victoria. She has transformed ADM into THE agency in the market.” 

Per the call for nominations, the award was presented to an individual responsible for leading the company’s digital sales team resulting in revenue increases directly associated with digital products. The criteria considered were measurable results of her efforts such as sales staff training and recruitment, product/service development and year-over-year revenue growth. 

“Jennifer has proven that hard work and dedication within the industry pays off. She has done an amazing job of executing the ADM strategy, moving up quickly in the ranks while taking on new responsibilities and assignments gracefully. She has flourished in this role and I’m proud that the Local Media Association has taken note of her accomplishments and contributions to the Advocate Digital Media team,” Holmes said. 

Advocate Digital Media is a full service digital advertising agency offering targeted digital campaigns, responsive website design and optimization, industry leading search engine strategies and social media plans for a variety of clients. The agency handles all forms of advertising and marketing, including branding, creative design, video production, outdoor, online, TV, radio, and print media planning and buying. Learn more at www.AdvocateDigitalMedia.com

objects.author: deepti@thewebplant.com
objects.html_title: Fourth Quarter: Fade To Black
objects.label: Fourth Quarter: Fade To Black

meta.post_summary: Hopefully, if you’ve been following this space for the past few months you’ve taken the action necessary to be ready for fourth quarter. Can you believe it’s here again?
meta.html_title: Fourth Quarter: Fade To Black
meta.meta_description: We do digital marketing with results that matter. From social media, web design, to digital advertising. We do it all.
meta.post_body:
Hopefully, if you’ve been following this space for the past few months you’ve taken the action necessary to be ready for fourth quarter. Can you believe it’s here again?

What does it really mean to be prepared?

You prepared a comprehensive budget with a healthy increase in digital marketing initiatives. eMarketer predicts a 15.5% year over year increase in ecommerce. However, as we’ve discussed in this space many times, a staggering 69% of consumers engage in reverse showrooming – or checking out a product online or on their mobile device before going into a retail store and making a purchase.

You have a responsive design website. A site that works equally well on smartphones, tablets and desktop computers is hugely important. More shopping will take place during fourth quarter 2014 on smartphones than on desktop and laptop computers combined.

You’re driving qualified, local audiences to your site and into your store. How are you reaching the younger, well-educated, affluent consumer? They’re hard to reach but valuable to the growth and stability of you business.

You have a well-planned, well-executed social media presence. Are your likes and post engagement growing on Facebook?

Your business ranks well locally on national search engines for products and services you offer. Consumers are searching – can you be found? Once all of your other marketing starts working consumers’ turn to the Internet to find out more. If you can’t be found you can be sure that your competition will be.

Your paid search campaigns and targeted display campaigns are converting well and getting buyers to your website across desktop, tablets and smartphones.

If you’re all set with the checklist above then you’re prepared for Fourth Quarter and the shopping frenzy that is about to take place. As a marketer, this is the most exciting time of the year!

2013 was an amazing year for mobile, social and all things digital. The 2014 holiday shopping season is sure to shatter all related records once again. Make sure you’re prepared to take part!

--

About: Jason Holmes is the General Manager of Advocate Digital Media, a sister company to The Victoria Advocate that focuses on digital marketing. He welcomes questions and column ideas. jtholmes@advocatedigital.com

objects.html_title: Advocate Digital Media is Now an Official Google Partner
objects.label: Advocate Digital Media is Now an Official Google Partner

meta.post_summary: Advocate Digital Media, a full service digital agency in South Texas, has been named a Google Partner. Being a certified Google Partner means that Google trusts Advocate Digital Media, who has demonstrated proven success using industry best practices to provide high quality digital marketing services. Google sets the standard across all online search engines for natural and paid search optimization.
meta.html_title: Advocate Digital Media is Now an Official Google Partner
meta.meta_description: We do digital marketing with results that matter. From social media, web design, to digital advertising. We do it all.
meta.post_body:
Advocate Digital Media, a full service digital agency in South Texas, has been named a Google Partner. Being a certified Google Partner means that Google trusts Advocate Digital Media, who has demonstrated proven success using industry best practices to provide high quality digital marketing services. Google sets the standard across all online search engines for natural and paid search optimization. 

With Partner status, Advocate Digital Media stays ahead of the curve by working directly with Google to provide the best level of service for their clients using the latest Google tools and products making sure they get the most out of their marketing budgets. The Google Partner badge isn’t just handed out; it’s earned. In order to achieve this certification, strict eligibility requirements must be met. Having passed all certification exams, Advocate Digital Media ensures expertise with managing Google accounts, continued best practices, and maintaining minimum spending levels. 

“We at Advocate Digital Media pride ourselves for our focus on staying ahead of the quickly shifting media landscape and responding to emerging trends that can reap rewards for our clients. By achieving this status as a Google Partner, we know the best practices that will drive success for our customers and clients,” said Jason Holmes, general manager of Advocate Digital Media.

Advocate Digital Media hosts livestream Google Partners Connect events periodically throughout the year. Those business owners wishing to attend and learn more about these educational events are asked to call 361-580-6553 or complete the contact us form on www.advocatedigital.com. Don’t miss these great opportunities to learn how to grow your business from Google experts!

objects.rss_body:
Advocate Digital Media, a full service digital agency in South Texas, has been named a Google Partner. Being a certified Google Partner means that Google trusts Advocate Digital Media, who has demonstrated proven success using industry best practices to provide high quality digital marketing services. Google sets the standard across all online search engines for natural and paid search optimization. 

With Partner status, Advocate Digital Media stays ahead of the curve by working directly with Google to provide the best level of service for their clients using the latest Google tools and products making sure they get the most out of their marketing budgets. The Google Partner badge isn’t just handed out; it’s earned. In order to achieve this certification, strict eligibility requirements must be met. Having passed all certification exams, Advocate Digital Media ensures expertise with managing Google accounts, continued best practices, and maintaining minimum spending levels. 

“We at Advocate Digital Media pride ourselves for our focus on staying ahead of the quickly shifting media landscape and responding to emerging trends that can reap rewards for our clients. By achieving this status as a Google Partner, we know the best practices that will drive success for our customers and clients,” said Jason Holmes, general manager of Advocate Digital Media.

Advocate Digital Media hosts livestream Google Partners Connect events periodically throughout the year. Those business owners wishing to attend and learn more about these educational events are asked to call 361-580-6553 or complete the contact us form on www.advocatedigital.com. Don’t miss these great opportunities to learn how to grow your business from Google experts!

objects.html_title: The Apple Watch Really Is A Game Changer
objects.label: The Apple Watch Really Is A Game Changer

meta.post_summary: The Apple Watch will change what the public expects from wrist candy and the ancient Swiss watch industry has shrugged the new watch off as a "transient product" rather than "items of enduring value." This is a classic example of the innovators dilemma theory, but with a twists.
meta.html_title: The Apple Watch Really Is A Game Changer
meta.meta_description: We do digital marketing with results that matter. From social media, web design, to digital advertising. We do it all.
meta.post_body:
The Apple Watch will change what the public expects from wrist candy and the ancient Swiss watch industry has shrugged the new watch off as a "transient product" rather than "items of enduring value." This is a classic example of the innovators dilemma theory, but with a twists.

Make no mistake, Apple is aiming at the midrange watch market and beyond. In July Apple CEO Tim Cook hired Patrick Pruniaux, VP of sales for Tag Heuer as well as ex Burrberry  CEO Angela Ahrendts.

objects.html_title: Does Your Agency Really Know Digital?
objects.label: Does Your Agency Really Know Digital?

meta.post_summary: Even here in South Texas, media consumption and consumer habits have shifted. Over the past two decades, digital channels have grown from little known websites and networks to the new mass media. Print media, broadcast television, terrestrial radio and relative newcomer cable television have given ground and market share to what used to be called “new media.” Digital media is now the mainstream media in 2014. In the future, it appears all media will eventually be digital. The trend doesn’t lie.
meta.html_title: Does Your Agency Really Know Digital?
meta.meta_description: We do digital marketing with results that matter. From social media, web design, to digital advertising. We do it all.
meta.post_body:
Even here in South Texas, media consumption and consumer habits have shifted. Over the past two decades, digital channels have grown from little known websites and networks to the new mass media. Print media, broadcast television, terrestrial radio and relative newcomer cable television have given ground and market share to what used to be called “new media.” Digital media is now the mainstream media in 2014. In the future, it appears all media will eventually be digital. The trend doesn’t lie.

We know from our interaction with local businesses and data sources like Borrell Associates that national and local businesses have made digital media the biggest chunk of their marketing and promotions budgets. Digital advertising is projected to comprise more than 35% of all advertising spend within our market this year – ballooning to nearly 55% in five years.

As a business owner that’s responsible for marketing, you owe it to yourself, your employees and even your customers to align your business’ marketing strategy with this digital reality. This is especially true when entrusting a partner like an advertising agency to execute your advertising and marketing strategy.

As we prepare for the fourth quarter, I’d encourage you to evaluate and reevaluate your advertising agency relationship. Digital marketing isn’t a fad or something that should be an afterthought in your overall marketing strategy. How do you verify a contender’s credentials?

Social Media: I’ll start with social, not because it’s the most effective marketing tool but because it’s probably the channel that we get the most questions about. Does your agency candidate “get” social media? Can they demonstrate and explain effective strategies that build audience but also ensure wide distribution of your marketing message and convert likes and followers into customers? At the very least, make sure that the agency you are entrusting with your social media strategy is active on social and growing their own social footprint. See how one business made signifcant strides in growing their footprint and developed an active social platform by clicking the link below to review our Booming Port Lavaca Social Media Case Study.

{{cta('1a0c8da0-0405-4e0b-bb96-6e187f8b0221')}}

Search: For the most part, the Internet is still all about search. With an incredible 68% in search engine market share, Google by far should be your primary concern in this space. Any agency worth your time to needs to understand Search Engine Marketing (SEM) and Search Engine Optimization (SEO). You shouldn’t have to be an expert as a customer but your agency needs to be able to execute on-page and off-page SEO strategies while complimenting organic search optimization with SEM campaigns that make sense and maximize your established budget. Poorly managed campaigns can quickly waste your budget and shouldn’t be handled by noncertified personnel.

Mobile: I’ve used this column to address mobile more than any other subject. The Internet is mobile. Social is mobile. Consumers expect your business to be accessible on their device. As a marketer, you get no better opportunity to reach consumers where they live on a platform that is closer to them than anything we’ve ever seen. Without a responsive design website and a mobile strategy, you’re missing a once in a generation opportunity. Questions to your agency on this subject should include case studies and references from customers that are reaching mobile consumers and have a completely mobile digital strategy. Another quick way to rule out an agency contender is to view their site on your smartphone. Is it completely unstable? Is it responsive? If the answer to either of these questions is no then I’d advise you to move on.

Digital Display: Your agency needs to be able to execute a targeted digital display campaign that extends your brand and message on national and niche sites all over the Internet. This type of campaign used to be a novelty but now it’s one of the fastest growing and most effective methods of reaching consumers when they’re ready to buy. If your agency isn't prepared to effectively explain, design and implement this type of campaign then you need to reevaluate your agency relationship.

Video: Digital video has come of age over the past few years. Services like Netflix and Hulu have changed the way consumers watch video and think about TV in general. Time shifting via DVRs was the first step in this disruption. Internet distribution on these platforms is speeding up. Be certain your agency can craft a plan to reach consumers across the most popular video channels.

This list isn’t entirely complete. Hopefully, this gives you a few talking points to address with your agency candidates.

About: Jason Holmes is the General Manager of Advocate Digital Media, a sister company to The Victoria Advocate that focuses on digital marketing. He welcomes questions and column ideas. jtholmes@advocatedigital.com

At the very least, make sure that the agency you are entrusting with your social media strategy is active on social and growing their own social footprint. See how one business made signifcant strides in growing their footprint and developed an active social platform by clicking the link below to review our Booming Port Lavaca Social Media Case Study.

{{cta('1a0c8da0-0405-4e0b-bb96-6e187f8b0221')}}

Search: For the most part, the Internet is still all about search. With an incredible 68% in search engine market share, Google by far should be your primary concern in this space. Any agency worth your time to needs to understand Search Engine Marketing (SEM) and Search Engine Optimization (SEO). You shouldn’t have to be an expert as a customer but your agency needs to be able to execute on-page and off-page SEO strategies while complimenting organic search optimization with SEM campaigns that make sense and maximize your established budget. Poorly managed campaigns can quickly waste your budget and shouldn’t be handled by noncertified personnel.

Mobile: I’ve used this column to address mobile more than any other subject. The Internet is mobile. Social is mobile. Consumers expect your business to be accessible on their device. As a marketer, you get no better opportunity to reach consumers where they live on a platform that is closer to them than anything we’ve ever seen. Without a responsive design website and a mobile strategy, you’re missing a once in a generation opportunity. Questions to your agency on this subject should include case studies and references from customers that are reaching mobile consumers and have a completely mobile digital strategy. Another quick way to rule out an agency contender is to view their site on your smartphone. Is it completely unstable? Is it responsive? If the answer to either of these questions is no then I’d advise you to move on.

Digital Display: Your agency needs to be able to execute a targeted digital display campaign that extends your brand and message on national and niche sites all over the Internet. This type of campaign used to be a novelty but now it’s one of the fastest growing and most effective methods of reaching consumers when they’re ready to buy. If your agency isn't prepared to effectively explain, design and implement this type of campaign then you need to reevaluate your agency relationship.

Video: Digital video has come of age over the past few years. Services like Netflix and Hulu have changed the way consumers watch video and think about TV in general. Time shifting via DVRs was the first step in this disruption. Internet distribution on these platforms is speeding up. Be certain your agency can craft a plan to reach consumers across the most popular video channels.

This list isn’t entirely complete. Hopefully, this gives you a few talking points to address with your agency candidates.

About: Jason Holmes is the General Manager of Advocate Digital Media, a sister company to The Victoria Advocate that focuses on digital marketing. He welcomes questions and column ideas. jtholmes@advocatedigital.com
objects.rss_summary: Even here in South Texas, media consumption and consumer habits have shifted. Over the past two decades, digital channels have grown from little known websites and networks to the new mass media. Print media, broadcast television, terrestrial radio and relative newcomer cable television have given ground and market share to what used to be called “new media.” Digital media is now the mainstream media in 2014. In the future, it appears all media will eventually be digital. The trend doesn’t lie.
objects.title: Does Your Agency Really Know Digital?

objects.author: deepti@thewebplant.com
objects.html_title: Digital Advantage: Engage the Moneymaker Effect
objects.label: Digital Advantage: Engage the Moneymaker Effect

meta.post_summary: In 2003, Chris Moneymaker, real name by the way, won the World Series of Poker Main Event and sent the worldwide poker boom into overdrive.
meta.html_title: Digital Advantage: Engage the Moneymaker Effect
meta.meta_description: We do digital marketing with results that matter. From social media, web design, to digital advertising. We do it all.
meta.post_body:
In 2003, Chris Moneymaker, real name by the way, won the World Series of Poker Main Event and sent the worldwide poker boom into overdrive.

Blogs, books and hundreds of magazine articles have been written about the phenomenon, which became known as the "Moneymaker effect."

What made this poker champion so different than the 22 previous winners? It was all about how he got there. Moneymaker wasn't a professional poker player. He was a 27-year-old accountant from Tennessee who had won his buy in to the $10,000 event by winning a $39 online tournament.

Millions of people watched an average guy turn $39 into $2.5 million and he got that opportunity online. Overnight, Moneymaker was a millionaire and everybody and their grandmother became an online poker player. The same tournament went from 839 entrants in 2003 to nearly 9,000 just three years later. The tournament's first prize grew from $2.5 million to a staggering $12 million. Online poker became a multi-billion dollar international industry. Poker was changed forever.

Many people think that poker got so outrageously popular because it was on TV. But poker has actually been on TV since the 1970s, first on CBS and later on ESPN. It wasn't until they added the online component that poker became a national obsession and cultural phenomena.

From a marketer's perspective, this is a great example of the symbiotic relationship between traditional and digital marketing. People see something in traditional media and then react online. This online activity then affects offline behavior. What was this effect in this case? By creating more online poker players, the industry created more offline poker players - to the point where they likely just consider themselves "poker players."

Similarly, consumers' physical and digital lives are converging. People aren't just online or offline "shoppers." They're just "shoppers." They shop with their smartphones while in stores, "showrooming," and they reverse showroom by shopping online before visiting stores. Showrooming is annoying for retailers but it's much worse for the business owner not to be found in the online shopping process.

Don't have a strong Facebook presence? Too bad, consumers expect you to be there for that part of their life.

No website or a website that doesn't work on their phone? You may as well not exist.

They use their smartphone for everything.

Not top of mind because all of your competitors are targeting your customers on their devices? You guessed it - not the consumer's problem. All they know is that they needed something, saw it online, bought it and moved on.

The next time a potential customer is in your store shopping and showrooming take a minute to think about all of the business being driven to stores by the Internet. If you improve your visibility online, social media and on mobile, play your cards right and you could cash in on the Moneymaker effect.

Jason Holmes is the general manager of Advocate Digital Media, a sister company to The Victoria Advocate that focuses on digital marketing. He welcomes questions and column ideas. jtholmes@advocatedigital.com

objects.html_title: Do Facebook Likes Have Real Value?
objects.label: Do Facebook Likes Have Real Value?

meta.post_summary: "Can you help me get more likes on Facebook?" This is a question we receive from local businesses all the time.
meta.html_title: Do Facebook Likes Have Real Value?
meta.meta_description: We do digital marketing with results that matter. From social media, web design, to digital advertising. We do it all.
meta.post_body:
"Can you help me get more likes on Facebook?" This is a question we receive from local businesses all the time.

The desire to increase likes on Facebook is understandable. Increasing your relevant social fan base should be a top priority for any business owner. With more than 51 percent of social logins and 63 percent of mobile logins in 2013, Facebook is the undisputed social media leader.

However, businesses are still struggling with monetization and assigning value to their social media audience. How many customers can a local business owner expect to gain through a social media campaign? What's the real value of a like?

As with all things marketing, the answer is "it depends." A targeted like, one from a user that is local, can afford your product and is in the demographic that you're trying to reach, can be extremely valuable. However, it works similarly to other advertising and promotion. Not every prospect is a good prospect. Even consumers who appear to be good ones are in the market for a certain product for short periods of time.

For instance, if you're a local auto dealer and have 1,000 likes on your Facebook page, you may think of all of these people as potential customers. However, how many of those people are actually looking to buy a vehicle at any one time? The truth is about 1 percent of the population is in the market for a new or used vehicle at any given time. This means that in this example, our auto dealer is reaching about 10 potential customers with every Facebook post, which is not bad, because the 1 percent rule for auto dealers is true regardless of the marketing vehicle chosen. It doesn't matter if it's digital advertising, print, TV or direct mail - 99 percent of the population isn't in the market for a vehicle. The 1 percent that is in the market can be extremely valuable, and some of them will be reached and converted into customers through social media.

 

{{cta('1a0c8da0-0405-4e0b-bb96-6e187f8b0221')}}

What about small, local businesses? Do likes have value for them? I would argue yes. They are even more valuable than for businesses that sell high-ticket items. Why? It's simple: frequency of purchase. Most consumers purchase a vehicle or a room full of furniture every few years. These types of retailers have to be relevant when the consumer is ready to buy. No way around it. But suppose you run or own a local restaurant, how often are consumers in the market for your product? You have an opportunity to reach hungry consumers every single day. Your social following and every aspect of the way you interact with them is extremely important to the success of your business.

In the next column, we'll dive deeper into how to build a targeted social following, why you shouldn't buy likes and whether advertising through Facebook's self-serve platform really makes sense.

Jason Holmes is the general manager of Advocate Digital Media, a sister company to the Victoria Advocate that focuses on digital marketing. He welcomes questions and column ideas at jtholmes@advocatedigital.com.

Jason Holmes is the general manager of Advocate Digital Media, a sister company to the Victoria Advocate that focuses on digital marketing. He welcomes questions and column ideas at jtholmes@advocatedigital.com.

objects.post_rss_content: "Can you help me get more likes on Facebook?" This is a question we receive from local businesses all the time.
objects.post_summary: "Can you help me get more likes on Facebook?" This is a question we receive from local businesses all the time.
objects.post_summary_rss: "Can you help me get more likes on Facebook?" This is a question we receive from local businesses all the time.
objects.rss_body:
"Can you help me get more likes on Facebook?" This is a question we receive from local businesses all the time.

The desire to increase likes on Facebook is understandable. Increasing your relevant social fan base should be a top priority for any business owner. With more than 51 percent of social logins and 63 percent of mobile logins in 2013, Facebook is the undisputed social media leader.

However, businesses are still struggling with monetization and assigning value to their social media audience. How many customers can a local business owner expect to gain through a social media campaign? What's the real value of a like?

As with all things marketing, the answer is "it depends." A targeted like, one from a user that is local, can afford your product and is in the demographic that you're trying to reach, can be extremely valuable. However, it works similarly to other advertising and promotion. Not every prospect is a good prospect. Even consumers who appear to be good ones are in the market for a certain product for short periods of time.

For instance, if you're a local auto dealer and have 1,000 likes on your Facebook page, you may think of all of these people as potential customers. However, how many of those people are actually looking to buy a vehicle at any one time? The truth is about 1 percent of the population is in the market for a new or used vehicle at any given time. This means that in this example, our auto dealer is reaching about 10 potential customers with every Facebook post, which is not bad, because the 1 percent rule for auto dealers is true regardless of the marketing vehicle chosen. It doesn't matter if it's digital advertising, print, TV or direct mail - 99 percent of the population isn't in the market for a vehicle. The 1 percent that is in the market can be extremely valuable, and some of them will be reached and converted into customers through social media.

 

{{cta('1a0c8da0-0405-4e0b-bb96-6e187f8b0221')}}

What about small, local businesses? Do likes have value for them? I would argue yes. They are even more valuable than for businesses that sell high-ticket items. Why? It's simple: frequency of purchase. Most consumers purchase a vehicle or a room full of furniture every few years. These types of retailers have to be relevant when the consumer is ready to buy. No way around it. But suppose you run or own a local restaurant, how often are consumers in the market for your product? You have an opportunity to reach hungry consumers every single day. Your social following and every aspect of the way you interact with them is extremely important to the success of your business.

In the next column, we'll dive deeper into how to build a targeted social following, why you shouldn't buy likes and whether advertising through Facebook's self-serve platform really makes sense.

Jason Holmes is the general manager of Advocate Digital Media, a sister company to the Victoria Advocate that focuses on digital marketing. He welcomes questions and column ideas at jtholmes@advocatedigital.com.

meta.post_summary: In this installment, we'll talk about the top four things every business owner should focus on when it comes to marketing their business in the digital world. • Great web presence: The first and most important aspect of your digital marketing plan should be your overall online presence. This includes your website, social media profiles, business directories and reviews on sites such as Yelp and Google+. Do you have incomplete or inaccurate business listings? Are your business hours, maps and other business details accurate? What about unanswered negative reviews? These are all important parts of your overall web presence.
meta.html_title: Your Digital Marketing Checklist
meta.meta_description: We do digital marketing with results that matter. From social media, web design, to digital advertising. We do it all.
meta.post_body:
In this installment, we'll talk about the top four things every business owner should focus on when it comes to marketing their business in the digital world. • Great web presence: The first and most important aspect of your digital marketing plan should be your overall online presence. This includes your website, social media profiles, business directories and reviews on sites such as Yelp and Google+. Do you have incomplete or inaccurate business listings? Are your business hours, maps and other business details accurate? What about unanswered negative reviews? These are all important parts of your overall web presence.

Social engagement: The second involves your social media presence. It's important that your business engages with its customers online. Posting on Facebook and Twitter can keep them aware of not only your business but also of sales and specials that will bring you more business in the door. It's important to engage with consumers online in order to build a better reputation and relationship with your clients. • Mobile accessibility: It's very important that your website have mobile accessibility or have a responsive design. Consumers these days are viewing websites on many different size platforms such as tablets and smartphones. You want your website to adjust to fit any screen size and still look as sleek as it does on a regular computer screen. Consumers can become frustrated if they try to view your website on their device, and it doesn't render properly.

• Digital advertising: It is the digital age and one of the best places to advertise is online. Digital advertising can target your audience online and raise brand awareness. It can also help your business become more competitive. It's a way for your small business to excel on a national stage.

Jason Holmes is the general manager of Advocate Digital Media, a sister company to The Victoria Advocate that focuses on digital marketing. He welcomes questions and column ideas. jtholmes@advocatedigital.com.

objects.author: deepti@thewebplant.com
objects.html_title: Mobile Continues Its March
objects.label: Mobile Continues Its March

meta.post_summary: When will big-box stores like Best Buy stop selling desktop computers? Sometime in the next three years - that's my prediction anyway.
meta.html_title: Mobile Continues Its March
meta.meta_description: We do digital marketing with results that matter. From social media, web design, to digital advertising. We do it all.
meta.post_body:
When will big-box stores like Best Buy stop selling desktop computers? Sometime in the next three years - that's my prediction anyway.

Now don't misinterpret, desktops will still be available for special order, primarily used for offices and store point-of-sale systems, but consumers are all but done with them already.

According to Gartner, global PC shipments fell 10 percent in 2013 with the trend speeding up in 2014. Meanwhile, tablet and smartphone sales have continued to grow, outpacing all PC sales, including laptops.

However, for you as a marketer, usage is a more important trend. Are consumers using their smartphones and tablets to shop? According to ComScore, they are. Eighty percent of smartphone owners use their device for shopping, and mobile adoption rates are eight times faster than web adoption rates in the 1990s and early 2000s. Smartphone and tablet usage will overtake desktop and laptop usage this year.

This migration to mobile is a huge cultural shift, and it's only speeding up. The local business owners I speak with are usually of one of two minds:

  1. This is a huge opportunity. I want to be where my customers and the next generation of customers are.
  2. I hate computers and the Internet. I can't compete with "the Internet," so I'm not going to try.

Business owners in the first group certainly hope that their local competitors think like group No. 2. When you see market trends as opportunities rather than just as threats, you can generally capitalize on expected changes.

One interesting way the local retailer fights back and actually capitalizes on mobile and the Internet as a whole is by having a professional Web presence that ranks well for terms, products and services that consumers are shopping for. This can lead to what's called "reverse showrooming."

Many of you are familiar with "showrooming" even if you aren't aware of the term. If you own or manage a brick-and-mortar store, you've seen consumers look over your products while comparing price and availability with online retailers on their phones. A staggering 46 percent of consumers are "showroomers." Sometimes, the consumer buys the product or services from you, and sometimes, they go elsewhere.

What you don't see are the consumers that "reverse showroom." That is, use their mobile device to shop for a product or service online and then purchase offline. It may surprise you, but 69 percent of American consumers are "reverse showroomers."

However, without a website that is responsive and works properly on all mobile devices, a social media plan and a digital marketing presence that reaches consumers where they live and shop, you're guaranteed not to participate in the "reverse showrooming" phenomena. Businesses in group one are already there.

The Internet has been a disruptive force over the past two decades. New business models like search engines and social networks have emerged while other business models like traditional media and home telephone service have been challenged. Mobile devices are simply the next evolution in the cultural shift away from being tethered.

Jason Holmes is the general manager of Advocate Digital Media, a sister company to The Victoria Advocate that focuses on digital marketing. He welcomes questions and column ideas at jtholmes@advocatedigital.com.

What you don't see are the consumers that "reverse showroom." That is, use their mobile device to shop for a product or service online and then purchase offline. It may surprise you, but 69 percent of American consumers are "reverse showroomers."

However, without a website that is responsive and works properly on all mobile devices, a social media plan and a digital marketing presence that reaches consumers where they live and shop, you're guaranteed not to participate in the "reverse showrooming" phenomena. Businesses in group one are already there.

The Internet has been a disruptive force over the past two decades. New business models like search engines and social networks have emerged while other business models like traditional media and home telephone service have been challenged. Mobile devices are simply the next evolution in the cultural shift away from being tethered.

Jason Holmes is the general manager of Advocate Digital Media, a sister company to The Victoria Advocate that focuses on digital marketing. He welcomes questions and column ideas at jtholmes@advocatedigital.com.
objects.rss_summary: When will big-box stores like Best Buy stop selling desktop computers? Sometime in the next three years - that's my prediction anyway.
objects.title: Mobile Continues Its March

objects.author: deepti@thewebplant.com
objects.html_title: Mobile continues to rise
objects.label: Mobile continues to rise

meta.post_summary: If you're still on the fence about whether you should invest your time and resources into responsive or mobile design for your business' website, consider this - back in May, Google's Matt Cutts said he "wouldn't be surprised" if mobile search exceeded desktop in 2014.
meta.html_title: Mobile continues to rise
meta.meta_description: We do digital marketing with results that matter. From social media, web design, to digital advertising. We do it all.
meta.post_body:
If you're still on the fence about whether you should invest your time and resources into responsive or mobile design for your business' website, consider this - back in May, Google's Matt Cutts said he "wouldn't be surprised" if mobile search exceeded desktop in 2014.

So very soon, without a mobile-optimized site, you could be missing more than half your audience.

It wasn't stunning this week to see Google announce it will now warn users when websites listed in their search results contain code not supported by their device.

Essentially, if your site doesn't play nice with smartphones and tablets, you can say goodbye to those traffic sources. IPhones, Android devices, Kindles and all other mobile platforms will be affected.

As Google continues to curate search results, there is no doubt that sites that support multiple platforms and provide a consistent user experience across all devices will be favored. More than a year ago, Google termed responsive design a "best practice." Now, it appears that not following that cue will begin to materially effect search engine results.

While Google is often accused of being heavy handed when it comes to the search engine's mysterious algorithms and unwritten rules, the company has been very active in giving back to the development community through Google's webmaster tools.

A quick visit to Google's Web fundamentals resource can get you well on your way to building a multidevice responsively designed site for your business.

Even if you're not the type to actually build your own site, I would recommend having a look around Web fundamentals if only to better understand what your contractor or agency is building for your business.

If you know you want to move forward with a responsively designed multidevice website, make sure you're dealing with someone who knows what they're doing. Many times, local business owners entrust their Web presence to friends, kids of friends, nephews or other folks they say "know computers" or "get that stuff," when in reality they're just hobbyists or have no idea how to position a business on the Internet in a way that gets real results.

If you entrust your 24-hour digital presence to someone, treat that decision the same way you would treat any other business decision, such as selecting a supplier or critical vendor.

Ask for references, certifications and logic behind the proposal. Do they practice what they preach and have a responsive design website of their own? Have they worked with companies in your industry or similar fields?

I've urged you to make 2014 the year of responsive design for your site, but let's do it right the first time.

Jason Holmes is the general manager of Advocate Digital Media, a sister company to the Victoria Advocate that focuses on digital marketing. He welcomes questions and column ideas at jtholmes@advocatedigital.com.

objects.html_title: Social Success Case Study from Advocate Digital Media  to be presented at 2014 Social + Mobile Conference
objects.label: Social Success Case Study from Advocate Digital Media  to be presented at 2014 Social + Mobile Conference

meta.post_summary: Victoria, Texas --- Advocate Digital Media is pleased to announce that their case study was one of three winners in the 2014 Social + Mobile Case Study Contest, winning registration and accommodations for the second annual Social + Mobile conference hosted by Borrell Associates, The Local Media Association and the Local Search Association.
meta.html_title: Social Success Case Study from Advocate Digital Media  to be presented at 2014 Social + Mobile Conference
meta.meta_description: We do digital marketing with results that matter. From social media, web design, to digital advertising. We do it all.
meta.post_body:
Victoria, Texas --- Advocate Digital Media is pleased to announce that their case study was one of three winners in the 2014 Social + Mobile Case Study Contest, winning registration and accommodations for the second annual Social + Mobile conference hosted by Borrell Associates, The Local Media Association and the Local Search Association. 

As part of the recognition, Advocate Digital Media will travel to Chicago August 20 – 21 to present their case study at the conference and discuss ways attendees can modify the contest to fit their clients’ needs and their local market.

Jason Holmes, general manager of ADM, said of the recognition, "I'm thrilled to share our success story from one of our valued clients: Regal Jewelers. We at Advocate Digital Media enjoy working hand-in-hand with our clients to deliver innovative social contests that strike a chord with the audience, are relevant and meet the established goals of our clients. In this particular case with the Regal Jewelers Valentine’s Day contest, we were able to craft a perfectly timed custom contest that provided valuable, measureable results. We look forward to sharing our story and answering attendees’ questions on how they can implement similar social contests in their market.” 

The Social + Mobile conference aims to help attendees address how they can take advantage of the dramatic increase projected in social spending on Facebook, Google +, other social platforms and in mobile marketing. Media executives from all platforms, including TV, radio, directory publishers, newspapers and more will be in attendance for the valuable takeaways.

objects.author: deepti@thewebplant.com
objects.html_title: How was your first quarter?
objects.label: How was your first quarter?

meta.post_summary: Spring has sprung, and that means that the first quarter of 2014 is over already. If you are like me, you wonder how this is possible.
meta.html_title: How was your first quarter?
meta.meta_description: We do digital marketing with results that matter. From social media, web design, to digital advertising. We do it all.
meta.post_body:
Spring has sprung, and that means that the first quarter of 2014 is over already. If you are like me, you wonder how this is possible.

It seems like we just finished the holiday season and all that goes with it, yet here we are at the end of March getting ready to plan summer campaigns for our clients.

However, before getting ahead of ourselves and looking too far ahead, I'd encourage you to reflect on the first quarter, measure your success versus the same period last year and make adjustments to your approach if needed. The growth within our market segment and our company was phenomenal. On the local level, it's looking like 2014 really is going to be the year of digital marketing.

The reasons for this accelerated shift are vast. Obviously the digital audience has exploded during the past few years. Last year was the first year we saw mobile and tablet Internet consumption overtake the desktop audience.

The Internet, once considered the "in-office media" became the everywhere media. This year, as the audience continues to shift more toward mobile platforms, digital video and radio services like Pandora, smart marketers are targeting this audience and carving out substantial portions of their advertising budgets to reach consumers wherever they are.

Back in December, I encouraged you to include digital in your marketing budget for 2014. Apparently, a lot of you had the same idea because we're seeing more and more local businesses finding new customers through these platforms.

I'll use this space to again encourage you to evaluate the digital marketing space, compare your business to national, regional and local competitors, and make sure you compete.

If you're like many local business owners, you may find digital advertising and marketing intimidating. After all, large corporations have departments dedicated to Internet marketing and niches within social, search and mobile. However, you have an advantage as a local business owner. You know your market and can craft a message that resonates locally. This is something very difficult to do from a corner office on Madison Avenue.

Internet marketing isn't something to be scared of or intimidated by. It's an advertising vehicle like no other. It's a tool that can help grow your business and compete like never before. It'll take a little time along with some trial and error, but the payoff can be huge.

I'll use this space to again encourage you to evaluate the digital marketing space, compare your business to national, regional and local competitors, and make sure you compete.

If you're like many local business owners, you may find digital advertising and marketing intimidating. After all, large corporations have departments dedicated to Internet marketing and niches within social, search and mobile. However, you have an advantage as a local business owner. You know your market and can craft a message that resonates locally. This is something very difficult to do from a corner office on Madison Avenue.

Internet marketing isn't something to be scared of or intimidated by. It's an advertising vehicle like no other. It's a tool that can help grow your business and compete like never before. It'll take a little time along with some trial and error, but the payoff can be huge.
objects.post_body_rss:
Spring has sprung, and that means that the first quarter of 2014 is over already. If you are like me, you wonder how this is possible.

It seems like we just finished the holiday season and all that goes with it, yet here we are at the end of March getting ready to plan summer campaigns for our clients.

However, before getting ahead of ourselves and looking too far ahead, I'd encourage you to reflect on the first quarter, measure your success versus the same period last year and make adjustments to your approach if needed. The growth within our market segment and our company was phenomenal. On the local level, it's looking like 2014 really is going to be the year of digital marketing.

The reasons for this accelerated shift are vast. Obviously the digital audience has exploded during the past few years. Last year was the first year we saw mobile and tablet Internet consumption overtake the desktop audience.

The Internet, once considered the "in-office media" became the everywhere media. This year, as the audience continues to shift more toward mobile platforms, digital video and radio services like Pandora, smart marketers are targeting this audience and carving out substantial portions of their advertising budgets to reach consumers wherever they are.

Internet marketing isn't something to be scared of or intimidated by. It's an advertising vehicle like no other. It's a tool that can help grow your business and compete like never before. It'll take a little time along with some trial and error, but the payoff can be huge.

objects.author: deepti@thewebplant.com
objects.html_title: Now Is The Time For Responsive Design
objects.label: Now Is The Time For Responsive Design

meta.post_summary: This isn't the last column I'll write about the mobile web audience. Globally, in North America and right here locally, smartphone and tablet usage has exploded over the past three years.
meta.html_title: Now Is The Time For Responsive Design
meta.meta_description: We do digital marketing with results that matter. From social media, web design, to digital advertising. We do it all.
meta.post_body:
This isn't the last column I'll write about the mobile web audience. Globally, in North America and right here locally, smartphone and tablet usage has exploded over the past three years.

In fact, looking over our own website analytics last month, I was shocked to see that mobile and tablet page views have officially surpassed desktop traffic.

Desktop visits on the Victoria Advocate's website have slipped just below the 50 percent mark while smartphone and tablet usage has grown 76 and 67 percent over the past year and cumulatively make up the largest slice of traffic on the site. This shift is profound in that desktop traffic will likely never make up the majority again. Ever. The cords have been forever cut and the audience is free to move about.

So why is what happens on a local media website important to you as a business owner? Media websites that are locally focused are usually a leading indicator of the local Internet audience and its behavior. Therefore, chances are your website is experiencing a similar shift in user behavior.

How does your website treat those mobile visitors?

Now is the time to get serious about responsive design. By implementing a standards compliant, responsive design website, you can ensure that users of desktop, tablet and smartphone devices all enjoy a feature rich experience that is formatted properly for their device.

As mentioned in an earlier column, Google declared responsive design a "best practice" and notes that this is Google's recommended configuration on the company's Webmaster blog.

Here is an excerpt from my previous column that defines responsive design: "Responsive web design is an approach that resizes the core site based on the screen size of the visitor. For instance, if I visit your site on my iPhone while another user visits on a tablet or desktop computer, we all see different versions of the same site. The details are technical for non-website developers but the beauty of responsive design is in its adaptive nature and single URL structure. If you, as a mobile device user, share a URL from a responsive site with friends on Facebook or through email then it doesn't matter what device your friends are using. The URLs are the same on a desktop computer, tablet or smartphone. There are no m.website.com or website.mobi URL structures to deal with and far less maintenance required once the responsive design is implemented versus redundant updates that need to be made on separate mobile and desktop iterations."

There is no confirmation that responsive design sites are given preferential treatment by Google when it comes to search engine results pages. However, Google doesn't reveal everything related to its search algorithms and including responsive design as a "best practice" speaks volumes in my book.

objects.author: deepti@thewebplant.com
objects.html_title: Advertising vs. promoting on social media
objects.label: Advertising vs. promoting on social media

meta.post_summary: Many local businesses confuse advertising with promotion and marketing or vise versa.
meta.html_title: Advertising vs. promoting on social media
meta.meta_description: We do digital marketing with results that matter. From social media, web design, to digital advertising. We do it all.
meta.post_body:
Many local businesses confuse advertising with promotion and marketing or vise versa.

The difference can seem subtle, but promotion and marketing are actually very different from advertising.

To illustrate, many local businesses promote their products and services on Facebook by collecting likes through contests and online promotions. Using Facebook's free tools and building a fan base is a marketing example.

Facebook also offers self-service tools to advertise your business. If you manage a page, I'm sure you've seen the "Get More Likes" button. The targeting capabilities are very sophisticated and flexible. However, there are some issues with Facebook advertising that you should be aware of.

As we discussed in an earlier column, there has been and continues to be a huge underground industry based around artificially increasing search engine traffic to business pages by tricking Google and other search engines into recommending pages as relevant.

This is called black hat SEO, and it's a cat-and-mouse game between the "black hats" and the search engines.

Similarly, there are now black hat social media practitioners that are more than happy to "sell your business likes." You can find several sites on the Internet that will give you a set price for say, 1,000 likes.

The issue with these sites is that most of those likes will come from click farms, where people are paid about $1 per 1,000 likes in developing countries like India, Nepal and Egypt.

As you can imagine, these likes are useless to local businesses that are trying to build a fan base, and Facebook bans this practice.

Your Facebook page can be penalized for violating this policy. Also, since the people who like your page from these sources usually will never interact with your page again and ignore content you post, they actually hurt your page by making it appear less relevant to Facebook. Facebook will then distribute your content to fewer and fewer fans.

However, Derek Muller, creator of the YouTube science channel Veritasium, reported on a disturbing trend in legitimate Facebook advertising last month. The video illustrates how a large percentage of likes acquired through Facebook's own advertising platform also often come from developing countries, and their behavior is similar to that of the click farm likes - low engagement from users that appear to "like" hundreds of competing brand pages.

So what's going on here? Is Facebook selling likes the same way the black hats are? Nobody knows for sure, but the prevailing thought is no.

But the black hats are still likely to blame. The same way Google and other search engines attempt to uncover link farms and networks, Facebook has targeted click farms and their customers for sanctions and removal. The theory is that this action has caused click farms to train their employees to behave more normally and to include legitimate advertisers in their click regiment.

So what's a local business that wants to grow their real Facebook audience to do?

The best answer I can give is to be authentic and interesting.

Post creative content and not just about your business or the brands you carry.

Inform your followers.

Run contests that you promote and advertise in other local media.

Most importantly, be patient. Social media success takes time, but it is the new word of mouth.

You can see the Veritasium video at advocatedigitalmedia.com/likes/.

objects.rss_body:
Many local businesses confuse advertising with promotion and marketing or vise versa.

The difference can seem subtle, but promotion and marketing are actually very different from advertising.

To illustrate, many local businesses promote their products and services on Facebook by collecting likes through contests and online promotions. Using Facebook's free tools and building a fan base is a marketing example.

Facebook also offers self-service tools to advertise your business. If you manage a page, I'm sure you've seen the "Get More Likes" button. The targeting capabilities are very sophisticated and flexible. However, there are some issues with Facebook advertising that you should be aware of.

As we discussed in an earlier column, there has been and continues to be a huge underground industry based around artificially increasing search engine traffic to business pages by tricking Google and other search engines into recommending pages as relevant.

This is called black hat SEO, and it's a cat-and-mouse game between the "black hats" and the search engines.

Similarly, there are now black hat social media practitioners that are more than happy to "sell your business likes." You can find several sites on the Internet that will give you a set price for say, 1,000 likes.

The issue with these sites is that most of those likes will come from click farms, where people are paid about $1 per 1,000 likes in developing countries like India, Nepal and Egypt.

As you can imagine, these likes are useless to local businesses that are trying to build a fan base, and Facebook bans this practice.

Your Facebook page can be penalized for violating this policy. Also, since the people who like your page from these sources usually will never interact with your page again and ignore content you post, they actually hurt your page by making it appear less relevant to Facebook. Facebook will then distribute your content to fewer and fewer fans.

However, Derek Muller, creator of the YouTube science channel Veritasium, reported on a disturbing trend in legitimate Facebook advertising last month. The video illustrates how a large percentage of likes acquired through Facebook's own advertising platform also often come from developing countries, and their behavior is similar to that of the click farm likes - low engagement from users that appear to "like" hundreds of competing brand pages.

So what's going on here? Is Facebook selling likes the same way the black hats are? Nobody knows for sure, but the prevailing thought is no.

But the black hats are still likely to blame. The same way Google and other search engines attempt to uncover link farms and networks, Facebook has targeted click farms and their customers for sanctions and removal. The theory is that this action has caused click farms to train their employees to behave more normally and to include legitimate advertisers in their click regiment.

So what's a local business that wants to grow their real Facebook audience to do?

The best answer I can give is to be authentic and interesting.

Post creative content and not just about your business or the brands you carry.

Inform your followers.

Run contests that you promote and advertise in other local media.

Most importantly, be patient. Social media success takes time, but it is the new word of mouth.

You can see the Veritasium video at advocatedigitalmedia.com/likes/.

objects.title: Advertising vs. promoting on social media

objects.author: deepti@thewebplant.com
objects.html_title: Do Facebook likes have real value?
objects.label: Do Facebook likes have real value?

meta.post_summary:
"Can you help me get more likes on Facebook?" This is a question we receive from local businesses all the time.

The desire to increase likes
meta.html_title: Do Facebook likes have real value?
meta.meta_description: We do digital marketing with results that matter. From social media, web design, to digital advertising. We do it all.
meta.post_body:
"Can you help me get more likes on Facebook?" This is a question we receive from local businesses all the time.

The desire to increase likes on Facebook is understandable. Increasing your relevant social fan base should be a top priority for any business owner. With more than 51 percent of social logins and 63 percent of mobile logins in 2013, Facebook is the undisputed social media leader.

However, businesses are still struggling with monetization and assigning value to their social media audience. How many customers can a local business owner expect to gain through a social media campaign? What's the real value of a like?

As with all things marketing, the answer is "it depends." A targeted like, one from a user that is local, can afford your product and is in the demographic that you're trying to reach, can be extremely valuable. However, it works similarly to other advertising and promotion. Not every prospect is a good prospect. Even consumers who appear to be good ones are in the market for a certain product for short periods of time.

For instance, if you're a local auto dealer and have 1,000 likes on your Facebook page, you may think of all of these people as potential customers. However, how many of those people are actually looking to buy a vehicle at any one time? The truth is about 1 percent of the population is in the market for a new or used vehicle at any given time. This means that in this example, our auto dealer is reaching about 10 potential customers with every Facebook post, which is not bad, because the 1 percent rule for auto dealers is true regardless of the marketing vehicle chosen. It doesn't matter if it's digital advertising, print, TV or direct mail - 99 percent of the population isn't in the market for a vehicle. The 1 percent that is in the market can be extremely valuable, and some of them will be reached and converted into customers through social media.

What about small, local businesses? Do likes have value for them? I would argue yes. They are even more valuable than for businesses that sell high-ticket items. Why? It's simple: frequency of purchase. Most consumers purchase a vehicle or a room full of furniture every few years. These types of retailers have to be relevant when the consumer is ready to buy. No way around it. But suppose you run or own a local restaurant, how often are consumers in the market for your product? You have an opportunity to reach hungry consumers every single day. Your social following and every aspect of the way you interact with them is extremely important to the success of your business.

objects.author: thibbard@advocatedigital.com
objects.html_title: Utilize co-op for digital marketing campaigns
objects.label: Utilize co-op for digital marketing campaigns

meta.post_summary: As a local business owner selling national or large regional brands, you are probably aware of co-op advertising. And if you aren't, you need to be.
meta.html_title: Utilize co-op for digital marketing campaigns
meta.meta_description: Utilize co-op for digital marketing campaigns
meta.post_body:
As a local business owner selling national or large regional brands, you are probably aware of co-op advertising. And if you aren't, you need to be.

Manufacturers and suppliers use co-op advertising to provide assistance to retailers, sharing the cost of local advertising. These programs can vary wildly and so can their value. However, if you are not utilizing co-op dollars to help pay for your marketing and advertising expenditures, then you are probably leaving real money on the table and missing opportunities.

Some co-op programs pay media companies directly while others allow the retailer to accrue co-op dollars and use them to pay for additional inventory. Regardless of the details, these programs are almost always a win for the store owner.

Until recent years, co-op programs were limited to traditional forms of advertising: print, terrestrial radio, broadcast or cable TV. However, the shift in recent years toward digital advertising has been as dramatic as the overall advertising spending increase. In fact, Ford Motor Co. announced last month that it is now requiring dealers to use 25 percent of its co-op dollars on digital media.

In July, this requirement doubles to 50 percent. Ford isn't alone in this. Chrysler, Scion and other manufacturers have modified their programs to encourage digital spending.

This is no surprise: Most consumers start their car buying journey online.

This trend isn't just limited to cars. In just the past year, we've worked with local businesses to help get their digital marketing campaigns paid for by Valspar, Tony Lama, Chamilia, Wrangler and others.

There are thousands of brands that have funds available for digital advertising support. Large national retailers generally have teams of people within their corporations to ensure that all co-op dollars across all product lines are used within each local market in addition to their existing marketing budget.

As a local business owner, you need to compete with these retailers. Fully utilizing manufacturer co-op programs can help you level the playing field. Just make sure you use the available funds wisely. Working with a team and media company that understand co-ops and can research your individual programs and brands ensures that you don't leave any money on the table.

objects.author: thibbard@advocatedigital.com
objects.html_title: Social Media, Who Cares?
objects.label: Social Media, Who Cares?

meta.post_summary: I'm sure by now you are aware of social media, but why should you care? Does social media even help your business?
meta.html_title: Social Media, Who Cares?
meta.meta_description: Social Media, Who Cares?
meta.post_body:
I'm sure by now you are aware of social media, but why should you care? Does social media even help your business?

The answer is yes, you should care, and yes, it helps your business.

Let me tell you why and how.

Social media sites and the people on them are having real-time conversations about your business that define your brand and its standing in the marketplace, good or bad.

These conversations are happening whether you choose to participate or not. Those real-time conversations can be measured, harnessed and monitored to drive highly relevant conversations across several channels.

Your social media marketing should be more than just creating a Facebook page or Twitter page. You want a return on investment and to drive sales for your business. You need to focus your social media strategy on positive engagement and how that engagement drives people into your business to buy a service or product.

Social media is word of mouth on steroids. What used to take your customer base months to spread around town could be done in less than 10 minutes. Use this to your advantage. Manage your brand's identity online and take part in the conversation about your business, related services and community.

Social media is important for nearly all business categories but particularly those that are service oriented. For instance, if you're a new restaurant owner and customers who visit your restaurant enjoy or hate the experience, they're likely to post something to their social media profiles. Keep this in mind when providing customer service in the real world as well.

Even checking in at a new or existing location can raise awareness within a community.

Find ways to encourage check-ins and likes. Contests and specials promoted and shared on social media sites, especially Facebook and Twitter, can be highly effective when executed properly.

You can use social media for marketing and sales, but one of your primary focuses must be customer service. Listen to your customers and then provide quick resolutions to problems or questions. Respond quickly to customers' requests, complaints and compliments. Seventy-one percent of consumers receiving a quick brand response on social media would likely recommend that brand to others, compared to 19 percent of customers who received no response, according to NM Incite's 2012 State of Social Media Report.

objects.meta_description: Social Media, Who Cares?
objects.name: Social Media, Who Cares?
objects.page_title: Social Media, Who Cares?

parent_blog.html_title: Digital Trends
parent_blog.label: Digital Trends (Deprecated)
parent_blog.name: Digital Trends (Deprecated)

objects.post_body:
I'm sure by now you are aware of social media, but why should you care? Does social media even help your business?

The answer is yes, you should care, and yes, it helps your business.

Let me tell you why and how.

Social media sites and the people on them are having real-time conversations about your business that define your brand and its standing in the marketplace, good or bad.

These conversations are happening whether you choose to participate or not. Those real-time conversations can be measured, harnessed and monitored to drive highly relevant conversations across several channels.

Your social media marketing should be more than just creating a Facebook page or Twitter page. You want a return on investment and to drive sales for your business. You need to focus your social media strategy on positive engagement and how that engagement drives people into your business to buy a service or product.

Social media is word of mouth on steroids. What used to take your customer base months to spread around town could be done in less than 10 minutes. Use this to your advantage. Manage your brand's identity online and take part in the conversation about your business, related services and community.

Social media is important for nearly all business categories but particularly those that are service oriented. For instance, if you're a new restaurant owner and customers who visit your restaurant enjoy or hate the experience, they're likely to post something to their social media profiles. Keep this in mind when providing customer service in the real world as well.

Even checking in at a new or existing location can raise awareness within a community.

Find ways to encourage check-ins and likes. Contests and specials promoted and shared on social media sites, especially Facebook and Twitter, can be highly effective when executed properly.

You can use social media for marketing and sales, but one of your primary focuses must be customer service. Listen to your customers and then provide quick resolutions to problems or questions. Respond quickly to customers' requests, complaints and compliments. Seventy-one percent of consumers receiving a quick brand response on social media would likely recommend that brand to others, compared to 19 percent of customers who received no response, according to NM Incite's 2012 State of Social Media Report.
